componenttext: Dean, congratulations. Best wishes to you for the future. And same to you as well, Mitch. I guess, first off, on Mactac, in the context of this business being sold by Bemis in '14 for less than what you're purchasing the European assets for, can you give us some color on why you passed on the asset 2 years ago? Was it being sold as one asset, including North America, and so antitrust maybe kept you away?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're not going to comment, actually, on the process that Bemis ran a few years ago. I think the key theme we can come up to what us buying this business for more than what the Platinum bought the whole business for, including the U.S., a few year
componenttext: Yes. So we're not going to comment, actually, on the process that Bemis ran a few years ago. I think the key theme we can come up to what us buying this business for more than what the Platinum bought the whole business for, including the U.S., a few years ago, actually, only 18 months ago or so. They've done a phenomenal job. The leadership within Mactac, particularly in Europe in really turning that business around, improving the profitability, leaning out the organization, so that's -- they created a lot of value in the last 18 months. And we see opportunities to leverage it from here and create even more value going forward.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Then Mitch, do you see any additive technology that you're acquiring with these assets? Or...
componenttext: Okay. Then Mitch, do you see any additive technology that you're acquiring with these assets? Or...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a complementary technology, overall. So they have a number of coding lines with various different adhesive capabilities. But if you look at within the graphics space, there's graphics and tapes to a smaller degree within this business, but there is v
componenttext: It's a complementary technology, overall. So they have a number of coding lines with various different adhesive capabilities. But if you look at within the graphics space, there's graphics and tapes to a smaller degree within this business, but there is very long life in casting films, which is something that we do quite well like shrink wrap and so forth, and then there's shorter-life promotional films for graphic materials. And they have a very strong brand and complement our strengths with how they go to market in their approach.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just one final one, on the customer loss in PSM you called out last quarter. Just to clarify, did that start impacting the first quarter? When I look at the Pressure-sensitive margins in the first quarter, up 140 basis points year-over-year, is there something or any items that sort of fall off as we move through the year that would keep you from that kind of variance year-over-year as we move through -- throughout 2016?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think we're in a record cycle from a margin perspective and really kind of at the peak for PSM. So I would anticipate we're going to have margin compression in the back half of the year. And we talked about this before, in the last couple of qua
componenttext: Yes. So I think we're in a record cycle from a margin perspective and really kind of at the peak for PSM. So I would anticipate we're going to have margin compression in the back half of the year. And we talked about this before, in the last couple of quarters, we've seen some modest benefit from deflation, net of price. And so it'd be really reasonable to assume that the business cycle we'll see offsets this gain. Additionally, we're seeing some signs of modest inflation in the commodities markets. And as I mentioned earlier, we are seeing some 1% change for performance tapes would be customer's program that's exiting, and that was a margin that was a little bit higher margin than the above average in the business as well. So it's a little bit of an impact to the second half as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And when you say margin compression, you mean lower margins year-over-year in the back half of 2016? Or just lower than we had...
componenttext: Okay. And when you say margin compression, you mean lower margins year-over-year in the back half of 2016? Or just lower than we had...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what we're talking about is, right now, we're at a record -- Q1 is really a record quarter for PSM from a margin perspective. So less about year-over-year and more about we are at a peak right now.
componenttext: I think what we're talking about is, right now, we're at a record -- Q1 is really a record quarter for PSM from a margin perspective. So less about year-over-year and more about we are at a peak right now.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. All right. And then in the quarter, just around the organic volume for Pressure-sensitive, 4%, how much of that was price and how much of that was volume?
componenttext: Okay. All right. And then in the quarter, just around the organic volume for Pressure-sensitive, 4%, how much of that was price and how much of that was volume?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So most of that came from price -- from volumes, sorry, and then about 3% of that came out of emerging markets.
componenttext: So most of that came from price -- from volumes, sorry, and then about 3% of that came out of emerging markets.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from the line of George Leon Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of George Leon Staphos from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Alex Wang sitting in for George. First question, it sounds like PSM was really a driver of the positive variance relative to your expectations. Can you talk a little bit more about the higher value-added segments and emerging markets, how su
componenttext: It's actually Alex Wang sitting in for George. First question, it sounds like PSM was really a driver of the positive variance relative to your expectations. Can you talk a little bit more about the higher value-added segments and emerging markets, how sustainable you think those trends are? And then on a related point, having now 4 or 5 quarters with the operating margins at the high end or above the long-term guidance range, are you in a position maybe to reevaluate the margin target for PSM?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so as far as your first question, the performance on the margins within PSM, so yes, it was basically margin beat in PSM was what caused us to beat our own expectations as a total company. And essentially, just the mix came in a little bit better, an
componenttext: Yes, so as far as your first question, the performance on the margins within PSM, so yes, it was basically margin beat in PSM was what caused us to beat our own expectations as a total company. And essentially, just the mix came in a little bit better, and we continue to drive growth within the high-value segments, so that was a key contributor to that factor. And within the emerging markets, we did see -- within China, we saw some modest growth. China -- the level of growth, as we've been talking about for 4 of the last 5 quarters or so, have -- had moderated from what we have seen traditionally. So it was in low single digits. However, that's being offset by pretty phenomenal growth in ASEAN as well as in India. So that's what's going on with the growth trajectory and the margins. One of the other things that came in a little bit better than we expected, we're expecting essentially neutral benefit on the net impact of price and raw material inflation. It came in a couple of million dollars better than our expectations, so that was a positive contributor as well. And remind me, Alex, what was the second question?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, just on the long-term target and whether you're in a position maybe to reevaluate that.
componenttext: Mitch, just on the long-term target and whether you're in a position maybe to reevaluate that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we're not going to reset targets. We established those targets for 2018. As we've always said, this business is an extremely high-return business even at those levels. And we've never seen them as a ceiling or a cap. And we're continuing to test o
componenttext: Yes, so we're not going to reset targets. We established those targets for 2018. As we've always said, this business is an extremely high-return business even at those levels. And we've never seen them as a ceiling or a cap. And we're continuing to test our limits and continuing to push this business, both on the top and bottom line, and that's something we'll continue to do. So we think it would be at this point, after a few -- 5, 6 quarters of outperformance, to just change the long-term trajectory or long-term targets is not the right time to do it.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And just as a follow-up, maybe switching over to RBIS. You could talk a little bit about why maybe the core products, we're not seeing some more acceleration in that. Maybe what your expectations are as we progress through the year and what yo
componenttext: Understood. And just as a follow-up, maybe switching over to RBIS. You could talk a little bit about why maybe the core products, we're not seeing some more acceleration in that. Maybe what your expectations are as we progress through the year and what you're hearing from your customers as we move into a heavier selling season.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in the core products, we are -- actually, I think what I commented on is we're starting to see early progress from the actions we've been taking. Now the revenue is actually down modestly. But recall, we said we were going to be more aggressive on
componenttext: Yes. So in the core products, we are -- actually, I think what I commented on is we're starting to see early progress from the actions we've been taking. Now the revenue is actually down modestly. But recall, we said we were going to be more aggressive on the pricing front with certain -- in certain categories, and we've done that. And so the volumes are actually up with value, and that's -- and I'm excluding RFID right now. They're significantly up if you include RFID. But volumes in our core products are up. And so we think we're seeing good signs. It's been consistent the last few quarters from volume growth perspective. Good trajectory there. In the contemporary or the department stores, we are still seeing volumes down, and a lot of that has to do with some of the challenges that a number of the department stores are seeing in their own marketplace today. As far as what customers are telling us, it's hard to give you an average. If you look at it, there's a number of customers that are doing quite well, a number of retailers and brands, and there's a number that are having their own challenges that they work through things. So overall, we're coming off of a winter season that was a little lackluster from a retail sales perspective. And so a number of the retailers from that have more inventory than they want to be having right now, and that is factoring into their thinking. On a broad base, if I had to characterize, I'd say cautious optimism is what the retailers and brands are looking at. And those that are even struggling, everybody's looking to get more productivity out of their existing retail footprint, and it's something what we can help them achieve that, particularly with RFID, and that's the focus of the conversations.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeff Zekauskas from JPMorgan.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: How do you feel about your working capital? I think your receivables were up year-over-year. Your sales were down. Do you think that you're managing working capital as well as you might -- do you expect it to be a use this year or a benefit?
componenttext: How do you feel about your working capital? I think your receivables were up year-over-year. Your sales were down. Do you think that you're managing working capital as well as you might -- do you expect it to be a use this year or a benefit?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in general, on our working capital, we -- a big part of the change is that we had some planned investments in inventory, primarily in the RFID space, to support the accelerated growth that we've seen in that business. So over time, we expect that, that
componenttext: So in general, on our working capital, we -- a big part of the change is that we had some planned investments in inventory, primarily in the RFID space, to support the accelerated growth that we've seen in that business. So over time, we expect that, that will even out. But we did plan on -- in making those investments to make sure that we made our customer commitments.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just quick on the receivables, that has a regional impact as far as regional mix. The higher growth in the emerging -- some of the emerging markets where we have long -- slightly longer terms has an impact on that. I'd say, overall, we can do a little mor
componenttext: Just quick on the receivables, that has a regional impact as far as regional mix. The higher growth in the emerging -- some of the emerging markets where we have long -- slightly longer terms has an impact on that. I'd say, overall, we can do a little more here on the working capital perspective. And so we saw some deterioration. Part of that is just due to mix and some strategic decisions that en com has done [ph] on inventory. We think we'd do more here.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Your corporate costs year-over-year were up a couple of million dollars, but your SG&A was down, I don't know, $22 million. Why was corporate up and SG&A down so much?
componenttext: Okay. Your corporate costs year-over-year were up a couple of million dollars, but your SG&A was down, I don't know, $22 million. Why was corporate up and SG&A down so much?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in general, we're going to see a -- each quarter, there's a little bit of variance that goes on with the corporate expenses, so you should expect it to be near from $20 million to $25 million a quarter. So it's within that variance that we see just bas
componenttext: So in general, we're going to see a -- each quarter, there's a little bit of variance that goes on with the corporate expenses, so you should expect it to be near from $20 million to $25 million a quarter. So it's within that variance that we see just based on timing on some of the expenses. As far as SG&A, as we've talked about, we've had a significant restructuring program, especially in RBIS, where the majority of their savings are coming through the SG&A line. So when you look at SG&A savings, the productivity -- primarily the restructuring is driving the improvement overall. We also had some favorable in currency -- with the currency change that also was favorable, but that was offset with higher employee costs.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Are RFID margins higher or lower than the RBIS average margin? Or is there much more difference...
componenttext: Okay. Are RFID margins higher or lower than the RBIS average margin? Or is there much more difference...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The EBIT margins are above the RBIS average.
componenttext: The EBIT margins are above the RBIS average.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And often you get a sense of the order pattern going into the second quarter. Retail sales in the United States have been a little bit on the weak side. Is that something that you're seeing? Or when you look at your order patterns so far, how does t
componenttext: Okay. And often you get a sense of the order pattern going into the second quarter. Retail sales in the United States have been a little bit on the weak side. Is that something that you're seeing? Or when you look at your order patterns so far, how does that appear to you?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The order patterns are consistent with the guidance we're giving overall. But just the real test is not entering the quarter, it's really how long the peak lasts throughout Q2. So if it ends a few weeks early, that obviously has a big negative impact to u
componenttext: The order patterns are consistent with the guidance we're giving overall. But just the real test is not entering the quarter, it's really how long the peak lasts throughout Q2. So if it ends a few weeks early, that obviously has a big negative impact to us. So it's consistent right now, but it's really now an early read. As we've said, we have limited for visibility. Last year, the peak season actually ended relatively early, and that was one of the reasons we had the decline last year in Q2. So consistent, but I'd say it's too early to give you any more color on how that will play out.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: How will you finance Mactac? Or how you...
componenttext: How will you finance Mactac? Or how you...

componenttextpreview: Yes, so we have ample capacity through both cash and our current credit lines.
componenttext: Yes, so we have ample capacity through both cash and our current credit lines.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So do you expect to borrow the whole amount or partly borrow? What's your plan?
componenttext: So do you expect to borrow the whole amount or partly borrow? What's your plan?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we're -- so specifically, we have plenty of capacity available in our credit lines that we can fund this transaction, and we'll look at long term what this means for us from a financial perspective. So we generally -- we have a CT program, and we've go
componenttext: So we're -- so specifically, we have plenty of capacity available in our credit lines that we can fund this transaction, and we'll look at long term what this means for us from a financial perspective. So we generally -- we have a CT program, and we've got some other credit available for us that we can use.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you give your accretion calculation for next year, do you assume cost cuts or that's without cost cuts?
componenttext: When you give your accretion calculation for next year, do you assume cost cuts or that's without cost cuts?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So there's very -- as I mentioned in my comments, there's very little that we've got into the number for next year for synergies. We really -- we'll have some from the procurement side. But the team, the Mactac team, has done a phenomenal job of investing
componenttext: So there's very -- as I mentioned in my comments, there's very little that we've got into the number for next year for synergies. We really -- we'll have some from the procurement side. But the team, the Mactac team, has done a phenomenal job of investing in the business and really streamlining it. So what we're getting is a business that's really complementary to our graphics business in Europe.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Christopher John Kapsch from BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Christopher John Kapsch from BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a follow-up on the -- on Mactac. Just -- so if I remember -- I mean, this is going back a while, that was probably over a dozen years ago that UPM-Kymmene tried to acquire all of Mactac globally. That was challenged domestically by the DOJ and, obvi
componenttext: I had a follow-up on the -- on Mactac. Just -- so if I remember -- I mean, this is going back a while, that was probably over a dozen years ago that UPM-Kymmene tried to acquire all of Mactac globally. That was challenged domestically by the DOJ and, obviously, didn't go through. I'm just wondering, back then, was there any challenges on the European side? And I guess if you could comment on that first. I realized...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Chris, this is Dean. No, so the answer is they're -- the answer is no, so only the U.S. Department of Justice was looking at anti-competitive practices. There was a -- in Europe, there was also an investigation of the industry that happened around the sam
componenttext: Chris, this is Dean. No, so the answer is they're -- the answer is no, so only the U.S. Department of Justice was looking at anti-competitive practices. There was a -- in Europe, there was also an investigation of the industry that happened around the same time, but the 2 weren't linked in terms of an antitrust linkage, so to speak. So they were independent investigations.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just -- could you just maybe provide some color on what sort of physical assets come with the acquisition? And then you did mention in your formal comments some of the things that the private equity sponsor had done to improve that business
componenttext: Okay. And then just -- could you just maybe provide some color on what sort of physical assets come with the acquisition? And then you did mention in your formal comments some of the things that the private equity sponsor had done to improve that business in Europe. Just wondering if that improvement was more a function of productivity and cost-outs? Or did they also grow the business? You could talk about maybe the growth trends for Mactac Europe in the last couple of years and how it looks going forward based on your due diligence.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So as far as the assets that we're acquiring, so there's 8 coding lines, and they have the capabilities across all different 3 primary adhesive categories: emulsion, hot melt and solvent. So that's what we're acquiring. And as far as what the compan
componenttext: Sure. So as far as the assets that we're acquiring, so there's 8 coding lines, and they have the capabilities across all different 3 primary adhesive categories: emulsion, hot melt and solvent. So that's what we're acquiring. And as far as what the company has gone through the last 1.5 years, they basically restructured down to a single manufacturing facility. They used to have more than one, and that's been the area of focus. And as far as the top line, this business is -- Mactac has an extremely respected -- well-respected brand in the graphics space and tapes spaces. And this business used to have some other unprofitable categories, specifically bulk roll label materials that they've exited over the last 1.5 years as well that were unprofitable and pretty low end. So the trajectory for the overall business isn't really indicative of what was going on in the underlying core. And yes, we know them as from what we've seen in the due diligence and also as competitors that they're well respected in the market, and it's a platform that we expect to be able to leverage and continue to grow profitably.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then one follow-up on just the regulatory, and I'm going to go back even further. But when you guys acquired Jackstadt many years ago, was there any antitrust issues or questions in Europe on that transaction? And then I guess that was more a pl
componenttext: Okay. And then one follow-up on just the regulatory, and I'm going to go back even further. But when you guys acquired Jackstadt many years ago, was there any antitrust issues or questions in Europe on that transaction? And then I guess that was more a play and roll stock materials versus it sounds like Mactac is exclusively on the higher-end graphics. Is that correct?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the -- you've got a good memory, Chris. So the Jackstadt acquisition, we did have filings in multiple jurisdictions around the world. You're correct also in that about 80% of the Jackstadt sales were in the bulk roll label category, although they did h
componenttext: So the -- you've got a good memory, Chris. So the Jackstadt acquisition, we did have filings in multiple jurisdictions around the world. You're correct also in that about 80% of the Jackstadt sales were in the bulk roll label category, although they did have a decent-sized graphics business as well. And we went through a second round of process with some of the regulatory authorities in Europe, specifically in Germany. So it took them, I think, 4 or 5 months, and then we've got the approval. So Mactac's business is primarily a graphics business and, by and large, with a little bit of tapes. It's a nice add-on to what we're doing. And these are both categories where we have relatively low market shares, respectively. So we've got -- I don't want to project how regulatory agencies will react, but suffice it to say that we wouldn't have done the deal unless we had some level of confidence that it would go through.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And then if I could just follow up on one on the -- just the comment about peak margins and some expectation that there'd be compression in the second half. If you look at some of the drivers, setting aside the raw material benefit that you got in t
componenttext: Sure. And then if I could just follow up on one on the -- just the comment about peak margins and some expectation that there'd be compression in the second half. If you look at some of the drivers, setting aside the raw material benefit that you got in this quarter, it seems as though you guys have been optimizing your customer mix, you've been driving growth in higher-margin, more value-added product lines, and you always have been terrific at optimizing your manufacturing, both from, I guess, contenting out the material content as well as just enhancing your operational run rates. And none of that seemed like it's in jeopardy in terms of not being sustained. So I'm just wondering why the commentary about maybe this flattening out or compression of operating margins over the balance of 2016.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chris. So overall, I think the way you've characterized it is right, and then I'll answer your question. We'll continue to drive growth and looking to have outsized growth in the high-value segments that obviously improves mix. And we've also been ta
componenttext: Yes, Chris. So overall, I think the way you've characterized it is right, and then I'll answer your question. We'll continue to drive growth and looking to have outsized growth in the high-value segments that obviously improves mix. And we've also been talking about instilling more discipline in our less differentiated segments with how we grow and ensuring that it's profitable growth there. And our productivity initiatives that is a core strength of ours, we continue to execute on, and have consistently done that and will continue to do that. As far as -- if you look at where the margins are in Q1, hence the comments we're comping from Q1 where we're expecting it to go forward, you normally have a seasonal reduction in those margins in the second half, late in the year. So we just want to highlight that there's some seasonal adjustments. We've got the impact of lower -- the tapes decline of one customer, which will have an impact. And the -- from a -- just purely from the purchase prices we have for raw materials and the selling prices, it was a modest benefit. And there was definitely some deflation in North America. And as we've talked about last time, we've actually been adjusting our own prices to our customers in those segments that are impacted the most. So it's -- we're at peak levels. You don't want to lock on. This time you can get to a new level and say, this is something you should baseline your models on and how you're thinking about it. I will tell you, our focus here is about growing this business and growing it profitably and continuing to see opportunities for how we can further expand margins, which also fit -- and this is a great business and a great platform. That links right into why we're trying to penetrate this space even more aggressively with acquisitions like Mactac.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mr. Scarborough, there are no further questions at this time. I will now turn the call back to you. Please continue with your closing remarks.
componenttext: Mr. Scarborough, there are no further questions at this time. I will now turn the call back to you. Please continue with your closing remarks.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Pamela. Well, I'd just like to say I'm excited about the company's future, probably more excited than when I joined more than 33 years ago. And I'd also like to say that the course that we've set in late 2011 and then committed to the longer-term
componenttext: Thanks, Pamela. Well, I'd just like to say I'm excited about the company's future, probably more excited than when I joined more than 33 years ago. And I'd also like to say that the course that we've set in late 2011 and then committed to the longer-term targets in 2012, it's working. And -- but there's more to come. I'm proud to have been part of making Avery Dennison the leading company that it is. I want to thank the leadership team, our employees, our customers and our suppliers for their creativity and commitment to our success. And I have enjoyed engaging with investors and financial analysts over the years, and I really appreciate the relationships that we've built. Thank you.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the second quarter ended July 2, 2016. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 10:00 a.m. Pacific time today through midnig
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the second quarter ended July 2, 2016. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 10:00 a.m. Pacific time today through midnight Pacific time, July 30. To access the replay, please dial (800) 633-8284 or (402) 977-9140 for international callers. The conference ID number is 21782907. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Cindy Guenther, Avery Dennison's Vice President of Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Demetra. Today, we'll discuss our preliminary unaudited second quarter results. The non-GAAP financial measures that we used are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP on schedules A-4 to A-8 of the financial statements accompanying today'
componenttext:
Thank you, Demetra. Today, we'll discuss our preliminary unaudited second quarter results. The non-GAAP financial measures that we used are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP on schedules A-4 to A-8 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release. We remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These forward-looking statements are made subject to the safe harbor statement included in today's earnings release. 
On the call today are Mitch Butier, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Anne Bramman, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.  I'll now turn the call over to Mitch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Demmy, and good day, everyone. I'm happy to report another quarter with strong growth in earnings and free cash flow. We beat our expectations for Q2 adjusted EPS by about $0.05, driven by another exceptional quarter in PSM. We continue to drive
componenttext:
Thanks, Demmy, and good day, everyone. I'm happy to report another quarter with strong growth in earnings and free cash flow. We beat our expectations for Q2 adjusted EPS by about $0.05, driven by another exceptional quarter in PSM. 
We continue to drive above-average growth in high-value products segments and improved our competitiveness and profitability across the entire portfolio, and we're making good progress with our business model transformation in RBIS. 
So starting with Pressure-sensitive Materials. As you know, our goal in PSM has been to create value by organically growing the top line of this high return business at 4% to 5%, while expanding operating margins. And I'm pleased to say that the team continues to deliver on both fronts. 
In the second quarter, we grew PSM sales by nearly 5% on an organic basis and expanded adjusted operating margins to a new high of 13.5%. Once again, the emerging markets were a key growth driver, up 10% in the quarter. 
From a product perspective, high-value graphics in specialty labels and materials continue to grow at rates well above the segment average, while sales declined for Performance Tapes due largely to the loss of a specific customer application as we discussed before. 
Overall, I'm very pleased with our progress in shipping PSM's portfolio mix towards the higher-valued categories. We expect continued benefit over the long term from our focus and investment in these areas, including acquisitions exemplified by the Mactac deal that we announced in April. 
As for the base business within PSM, what we have often referred to as less differentiated products, we continue to deliver in the second quarter with solid top line growth overall and margins expanding across the board. 
Speaking of which, overall profitability for PSM exceeded our expectations, reflecting leverage on strong volume growth, continued disciplined with respect to pricing in the base business and of course, exceptional execution on the productivity front. 
Shifting now to Retail Branding and Information Solutions. Sales were up a little over 2% organically, driven by Radio Frequency Identification. I'm happy to report that RFID sales were up nearly 50% in Q2. 
The case for RFID is clear, and we remain the go-to supplier in the market so expect it to continue to be a key growth driver market for us going forward. 
Outside of RFID, top line growth was short of our target for the quarter, amidst the challenging apparel market. In particular, continued challenges experienced by the department stores and inventory reduction associated with athletic goods store closures. 
That said, we are seeing signs of success from our multi-year transformation strategy, becoming faster, simpler and more competitive while driving margin expansion. 
Specifically, we saw solid volume gains in both the value and fast fashion segment of the market during Q2 and unit volume for the department stores were relatively stable, an improvement over recent trends. 
We are also on track to deliver planned restructuring savings from the transformation. With these actions we're taking to improve our competitiveness in the base business, along with a list from RFID, even in a relatively modest apparel retail market, I am confident that we'll achieve our 2018 margin target for RBIS. 
Now looking at Vancive Medical Technologies. While this business reported solid margin expansion in the quarter, we are not yet performing at the level we expect.  We've began taking actions mid-last year that are beginning to refill our product pipeline and have recently reestablished the organization between Vancive and Performance Tapes business. 
Long term, these actions combined with strong growth from our new product platform should enable us to deliver consistent organic growth and double-digit margins in this business. 
So coming back to the total company view. In terms of our outlook for 2016, we have raised our adjusted EPS guidance by $0.05, reflecting the strong results we delivered in the second quarter. 
Even more important, we remain highly confident in our ability to consistently deliver exceptional value over the long run based on the execution of our key strategies. 
First and foremost, being our focus on driving outside growth in high-value segments. We will continue to invest disproportionately here, both organically and through bolt-on acquisitions. Over time, this will improve our portfolio mix and bolster our leadership in these key segments. 
Second, we are relentless in our pursuit of productivity improvement to enhance our competitiveness across all product categories and of course, drive margin expansion. 
And third, we are maintaining our high degree of capital efficiency, while increasing investments to support profitable growth. And of course, we will continue our disciplined approach to returning cash to shareholders. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Anne.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mitch. I'll be providing a little more color on the quarter. In Q2, we delivered a 20% increase in adjusted earnings per share on 4% organic sales growth. Currency translation were due to reported sales by 1.7% in the second quarter with an appr
componenttext:
Thanks, Mitch. I'll be providing a little more color on the quarter. In Q2, we delivered a 20% increase in adjusted earnings per share on 4% organic sales growth. 
Currency translation were due to reported sales by 1.7% in the second quarter with an approximately $0.03 impact on EPS. 
Adjusted operating margin in the second quarter improved 120 basis points to 10.7% as the benefit of productivity initiatives and higher volume more than offset the net impact of price and raw material input costs and higher employee-related expenses. 
We realized about $21 million of incremental savings from restructuring charges to net of transition cost. 
The adjusted tax rate was 34%, consistent with the anticipated full year tax rate in the low to mid-30% range. 
Year-to-date, free cash flow was $152 million, an increase of $38 million compared to last year, reflecting the increase in earnings and timing of tax payments. 
During the first half of the year, we repurchased approximately 2.4 million shares and paid $70 million in dividends. Net of dilution, we reduced our share count by 1.2 million through a net cost of $190 million, bringing the total amount of cash, return to shareholders so far this year to roughly $190 million. 
Our balance sheet remains strong, and we have ample capacity to fund acquisitions as well as to continue returning cash to shareholders in a disciplined manner. 
Now looking at the segments. Pressure-sensitive Materials sales were up approximately 5% on an organic basis. Emerging markets continue to be strong contributors to growth for this segment, with organic growth of 10%, emerging markets represented a majority of the segment's top line growth in Q2, in line with the preceding quarter and our long-term expectations. 
A key exception to the strong growth trends is in China, where sales were roughly flat in the quarter on an organic basis. 
In North America, sales declined modestly on an organic basis, while Western Europe remains solid, up mid-single digits. As noted previously, we continue to see strong growth in many at PSM's higher-value segments. 
Within Label and Packaging Materials, specialty films and tape products were up 10% on an organic and graphics grew high single digits. 
In contrast, sales of Performance Tapes were down mid-single digits on an organic basis for the reasons we've discussed. 
PSM's adjusted operating margin of 13.5% was up 120 basis points over last year as the benefits from productivity and higher volume more than offset higher employee-related costs and a net impact of price and raw material input cost. 
And by the way, that net gap between deflation and pricing was a modest negative for the quarter. We want to highlight it given the change of direction from preceding quarters. 
Once again, the team delivered the majority of this quarter's margin improvement through ongoing productivity efforts, including product re-engineering and restructuring. 
Now shifting to Retail Branding and Information Solutions. RBIS sales grew 2% on an organic basis, driven by growth of Radio Frequency Identification products, which were up nearly 50% in the quarter. We now anticipate full year sales for these products to be up more than 30% in 2015, recognizing that the comp is significantly more challenging in the second half. 
Adjusting for the impact of RFID, organic growth for core labels and tags were down low single digits, reflecting modest growth in volume, which was more than offset by the impact of strategic pricing actions that we began to take late last year. As you know, we began lowering our prices in some categories late in 2015 to become more competitive. So the sales growth comparisons become easier in the work quarter. 
From a regional perspective, we saw strong unit volume growth [indiscernible] 13 retailers and brand owners. This reflects excellent progress in expanding our share among the fast fashion players. In contrast, unit volumes declined in the U.S., where we have a relatively high share position among department stores. Notwithstanding the modest volume growth and pricing adjustments we've made, adjusted operating margins for the segment improved by 30 basis points, reflecting the benefit of the restructuring and other cost-reduction actions we've taken to transform our business model.  We remain on track to achieve our margin target for this business by 2018. 
Turning now to our outlook for the balance of the year. We have raised the range of our guidance for adjusted earnings per share by $0.05 to $3.80 to $3.95. We outlined some of the key contributing factors to our EPS guidance on Slide 8 of our supplemental presentation material. Highlighting the changes from our previous guidance, we now expect the currency translation will reduce net sales by approximately 2.5% and pretax earnings by roughly $18 million for an estimated $0.13 per share, $0.02 worse than our April guidance. 
We have reduced the high end of our organic growth outlook and now expect full year sales to grow between 3% and 4% on an organic basis. We anticipate that the Mactac deal will close in August, resulting in roughly 1 point of incremental sale with an immaterial impact to EPS this year, reflecting various transition costs. We have reduced our estimate for severance and other restructuring-related costs included in reported EPS by approximately $0.05. 
So just wrapping up, we're very pleased with the strategic and financial progress we've made against our 2018 goals in the past quarter. I'm confident we will continue to deliver exceptional value over the long term to appear execution of our strategies, including the disciplined allocation of capital. 
And now we'll open the call up for your questions.

componenttext: First off, on the PSM emerging market growth of 10%-plus, I know you called out China as being flat across emerging markets. But what about some of the other regions on the emerging markets side, Brazil, Southeast Asia, et cetera? And then what was North America up to during the quarter?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so just document the emerging market. So China was relatively flat as Anne commented on. Everything else has pretty exceptional growth. If you look at Southeast Asia, that was healthy double digits as was India and Eastern Europe return to good growt
componenttext: Yes, so just document the emerging market. So China was relatively flat as Anne commented on. Everything else has pretty exceptional growth. If you look at Southeast Asia, that was healthy double digits as was India and Eastern Europe return to good growth trajectory as well. Some of that, we think, as a little bit the pipeline fill within in the quarter, but even if you back that out, return to a healthy growth level. And Latin America, we continue to see solid growth a lot of that comes from pricing, as you know, but even on the volume front, we saw a return to growth, particularly in Brazil. Now some of that has to do with the elections that come up, they always have a benefit for us and not sure what the impact is specifically from the Olympics but we assume that, that had some positive lift as well. So pretty broad-based on the emerging market exposure, and you're seeing a little bit of shift. If you look at the last number of years, China was the lead driver of the emerging market growth, and we're starting to see there our strategy being the leader in all markets is paying off while China starts to slow down. The rest of the emerging markets is carrying the load. And then North America, we said, it was down modestly.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just generally on the RBIS outlook I mean, obviously, apparel has been mixed in North America for a while now. I know you have some company-specific initiatives to gain share in the market, but are there any adjacent markets that you see opportu
componenttext: Okay. And just generally on the RBIS outlook I mean, obviously, apparel has been mixed in North America for a while now. I know you have some company-specific initiatives to gain share in the market, but are there any adjacent markets that you see opportunities in the sort of diversified away from retail apparel, to some extent, over time?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there's 2 specific items. One is if you think about RFID, RFID is really an intelligent label, and we are looking at how do we -- the first place to adopt was in the apparel market and we're  vertically integrated they're looking at how we leverag
componenttext: I think there's 2 specific items. One is if you think about RFID, RFID is really an intelligent label, and we are looking at how do we -- the first place to adopt was in the apparel market and we're  vertically integrated they're looking at how we leverage our manufacturing prowess as a company at large and specifically, the knowledge within RBIS and RFID to leverage that more broadly, which is something we think will be a key growth driver for us in the long term. The other one, which certainly reduced exposure to apparel but does play the growth driver for us is the external embellishment so the heat transfer labels. This business, if you look 10 years ago, was only about the heat transfer label on the interior garment. We are going to be exterior garment where it's actually part of the branding that is displayed, whether it be for brands or sports teams and so forth. And that will continue to be a key growth driver for us as well.

And the second thing is normal seasonality this business as well. And so if you think about it, second half, here, it doesn't have the same profitability ratio that you have in the first half of the business that you would see.

componenttext: [indiscernible] from my perspective, we've been consistent in saying we're going to test new heights and we're going to continue to do that. And we continue to test new heights and clearly, we don't feel limited by the targets we set long term or anything else. So that's what we're going to continue doing as Anne commented on.

componenttext: Yes, so it's always pressuring actions of various levels but specific actions we took late last year, we do cycle through beginning in the second half, so it blends in beginning in Q3 through the end of Q4. So we do cycle through that then. And as far as from a share gain perspective, relative to the growth that we're seeing within fast fashion, our growth levels are exceeding the end markets, so we're  very comfortable taking share there. From a value perspective, we believe we're taking share with the the value. And contemporary, so department stores has to read, as I commented on the volumes there or the trends that we're seeing are positive, and we're seeing their performance in the marketplace. We believe we are now regaining share there. That was a space if you recall, along with value, we were losing share on -- up until beginning late last year, if you will. So we believe we're starting to shift the share mix overall for those businesses, but we'll have to see how their performance plays out here over the next couple of quarters.

componenttext: It's broad-based, but just the whole. I mean, the economy in South Asia, both Southeast Asia as well as India are doing quite well, and you continue to see expanded consumer spending. So it's consumer products linked as well as variable information labels as well and is very broad-based, and it's a very healthy double-digit growth there. I just got back from a 3-week trip over in Asia, and I'll tell you just -- when you're engaging with customers and so forth, they're quite optimistic about the prospects for their countries and their individual industries and excited about what's going to come. And we think we're key partners for them helping ourselves but helping them growth and lead the markets to GDP for us -- type of growth.

componenttext: That's good to hear. Just one last one for me on RBIS and I guess, RFID, in particular. I think you said you expected it to be up 30% at the current run rate. How big would that make the RFID business for you if you actually achieved a 30% rate? And then in addition to that, how are the recent rollouts been going? Have you seen any customers interested in moving from test to broad-based rollout? Can you just give an update there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the business after this year will be roughly $200 million for the full year, so pretty sizable relative to the full size of RBIS. And I think it's an important thing to point out. If you look at RFID and our external embellishment, it's roughly 1
componenttext: Sure. So the business after this year will be roughly $200 million for the full year, so pretty sizable relative to the full size of RBIS. And I think it's an important thing to point out. If you look at RFID and our external embellishment, it's roughly 15% of total RBIS right now where it was 6% just 5 years ago. And for the whole thing we're  talking about continuing to improve our portfolio mix and higher-value product lines. It's a great example this going out within RBIS as well. So there's a number -- we don't talk about specific customers within RFID who is going to full rollout and so forth. But I would tell you the pipeline's rich. We've got about 90 customers in the total pipeline, a blend between those that are in full adoption, those are in the rollout, those that are in pilot, and those it's a very early stages and just evaluating the business case. So we continue to see great progress. And as I said before, we are -- we do have a go-to team for RFID adoption, and that's something that a leadership position we expect to maintain.

componenttext: It's hard to pinpoint to any one thing. Specifically, within the quarter, there is a number of puts and takes for being the press down to the low single digits or roughly flat, but no key takeaways right now. And I will say for our business, a single quarter being flat to growing a few percent, that can happen. Our expectation here is mid-single digits for China.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just moving sort of Western around the world to Europe. I'm just wondering if the trends there have continued to pretty bouyant considering what's been out over there. And I'm just curious if there's been any change in those trends since th
componenttext: Okay. And then just moving sort of Western around the world to Europe. I'm just wondering if the trends there have continued to pretty bouyant considering what's been out over there. And I'm just curious if there's been any change in those trends since the Brexit vote, I guess, around a month ago.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually too early to tell, overall, is what I would say. Clearly, I think the broader question is just what does it mean for the EU and so forth. But if you look at where we are, our market leadership position regardless of market environment, we ar
componenttext: It's actually too early to tell, overall, is what I would say. Clearly, I think the broader question is just what does it mean for the EU and so forth. But if you look at where we are, our market leadership position regardless of market environment, we are well positioned for this and the U.K. business is just a little over $100 million worth of business, so relatively small in the grand scheme of things. First, I think it's a little bit blown out of proportion, a little bit some of the market reaction initially with what we saw, but we're well positioned and if there's some challenges in the marketplace, we're going to be taking advantage of those as the market leader.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I can just follow up on this Pressure-sensitive segment margin topic. And I know you kind of referred the first quarter performance, which was strong as possibly approaching peak and now, we exceeded that performance by 60 basis points sequen
componenttext: Okay. And if I can just follow up on this Pressure-sensitive segment margin topic. And I know you kind of referred the first quarter performance, which was strong as possibly approaching peak and now, we exceeded that performance by 60 basis points sequentially. And it sounds as though like mix is obviously operational excellence is contributing but also mix with the growth that you've seen in international markets, which I believe are higher margin and obviously your emphasis on shifting towards the more value-added products. And it sounds like that's all going to continue, particularly with investment in accelerating the growth of those sorts of product lines. So just wondering, given how well you're executing and given the trajectory of those higher-margin businesses, what -- just what's may be a more realistic longer-term margin expectation for this Pressure-sensitive segment as we continue moving forward here.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're not resetting margin targets right now. We've said that this business margins that we've had even 11%-plus, very healthy returns and our focus is, again, finding the right balance as top line growth, margins and capital efficiency to optimiz
componenttext: Yes. So we're not resetting margin targets right now. We've said that this business margins that we've had even 11%-plus, very healthy returns and our focus is, again, finding the right balance as top line growth, margins and capital efficiency to optimize EVA. So we will be setting new targets. When we come out, we're going to do an Investor Day. We're now planning for that to be in March, and we will send out a press release with the exact dates year in due time. But that will be the time that we reset it. And again, I to emphasize here the previous targets we have a clearly don't feel limited by those in any way. We are going to continue driving forward and finding that optimum balance. And again, expanded margin about 300 basis points over the last few years. And remember, we've got questions about resetting targets beginning 1.5 years ago. How we set them? We probably talking about should we be resetting them, again, right now given where our performance is. So we are setting new heights, and we'll continue to do so, and we'll update everybody with our long-term expectations in March.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well, and just one follow-up, and you'll  continue to get the question until you do reset the margins, I'm thinking, but I'm just wondering if your -- are you constrained given the margin performance and how this businesses are done, are you constr
componenttext: Right. Well, and just one follow-up, and you'll  continue to get the question until you do reset the margins, I'm thinking, but I'm just wondering if your -- are you constrained given the margin performance and how this businesses are done, are you constrained anywhere, where you feel like you need to ramp up capital in order to capitalize on growth in the Pressure-sensitive division?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, I wouldn't say constrained, but we said that we're going to be increasing the pace of capital investment within this business. If you look at the growth rate to your point, we do need to increase the pace of capital investment that is something
componenttext: Yes. Well, I wouldn't say constrained, but we said that we're going to be increasing the pace of capital investment within this business. If you look at the growth rate to your point, we do need to increase the pace of capital investment that is something we would expect given the long-term targets that we've laid out a couple years ago, it was roughly average of a couple hundred million dollars in the horizon. We haven't been on that pace until now, but we do expect to be ramping up here, specifically to capture profitable growth to your point.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Leon Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, the first question I had or beating the Pressure-sensitive margin question into the ground. But would you expect from the current level in the second quarter that you achieved that we should be seeing some flattening out from here seasonally? Or
componenttext: I guess, the first question I had or beating the Pressure-sensitive margin question into the ground. But would you expect from the current level in the second quarter that you achieved that we should be seeing some flattening out from here seasonally? Or is that getting too close for comfort and the commentary about 1Q being perhaps close to peak may be -- created core more distraction needed to be and we should just let you run your business and where ever the margins come out, they come out?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first, I like that second option, but I guess, I have to address the first question. So look, as I talked about, even the in last quarter's comments, first of all, we are hitting new heights as I talked about. We do have seasonality in this business
componenttext: Well, first, I like that second option, but I guess, I have to address the first question. So look, as I talked about, even the in last quarter's comments, first of all, we are hitting new heights as I talked about. We do have seasonality in this business and I think you've seen that historically and traditionally Q4, in particular, has quite a different margin when you look at historical trends on this. I would say that -- and as I mentioned, we also have the headwind is a performance take the customer in the second half. So when you look at the high end of the range, you would have to assume that we can leverage, sustain it and overcome some other -- some of these issues as well. But at the high end, it's really sustaining, they're continuing through and overcoming some of the performance take customer loss.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so George just to reinforce what Anne said. We typically see a drop in Q4 by a full point, and we've talked about tapes, the decline on the volume side. That is the high-margin business, and so that will have a pretty decent impact on the margins as
componenttext: Yes, so George just to reinforce what Anne said. We typically see a drop in Q4 by a full point, and we've talked about tapes, the decline on the volume side. That is the high-margin business, and so that will have a pretty decent impact on the margins as well. And as Anne said, full range of our guidance we think cash the full  range of possible outcomes, but probable outcomes and the high-end has roughly continuation, excluding a little bit of the excess in Q2 continuation margin trends we saw into first half continuing to the second half with a normal seasonal drop and the impact of performance tapes.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, I appreciate that additional color, that helps. If we talk about RFID, so I remember from the last quarter, you're expecting 20% growth thereabouts and now, you're in excess of 30%, so I think a lot of the answer here is in relation to what you're s
componenttext: Okay, I appreciate that additional color, that helps. If we talk about RFID, so I remember from the last quarter, you're expecting 20% growth thereabouts and now, you're in excess of 30%, so I think a lot of the answer here is in relation to what you're saying to I think Scott's question about RFID. But have you seen more customers coming to you for trials as the reason for the increase in the growth rate? Or has it been a greater amount of sales in existing trials that's been driving the increase in the guidance there for the full year, obviously, a tougher comes in the second half?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally, the latter. So it's an increase in sales to customers that already in the process of rolling. So just being more aggressive, if you will, the customers in the rollout so that's been the primary driver. As far as customers switching into full ad
componenttext: Generally, the latter. So it's an increase in sales to customers that already in the process of rolling. So just being more aggressive, if you will, the customers in the rollout so that's been the primary driver. As far as customers switching into full adoption, if you will, in the role out, that's something that usually there's a pretty short lead time from when that's announced so when we start sourcing that. So the key question here, we talked a little bit of tough comps in Q4, pressuring anybody else convert to that next level, which we've seen in the past, as you know.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. The last question I had, and I'll turn it over as most of my questions have already been asked. When we look at RBIS and I think you said you're ultimately constructive or pleased with Baird of business is, and I'm putting words in your mouth
componenttext: Understood. The last question I had, and I'll turn it over as most of my questions have already been asked. When we look at RBIS and I think you said you're ultimately constructive or pleased with Baird of business is, and I'm putting words in your mouth so feel free to adapt as you need to. But when I look at the margin, where the margin dollars your near being flat versus 2Q in spite of the $60 million net benefit that, that segment is getting from restructuring and other performance improvements, are you really happy with that business? Should we assume that all of that benefit has been basically used to grow market share through pricing and other actions? And should we expect a continuation of the labor and maybe even an intensification of the strategies that play book that ultimately, try to grow volume and margin for the segment over the next 12 to 18 months?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, George. Yes, so just the comment around RBIS is, we are pleased with the progress we're making of the transformation, which we are very pleased with our growth that we're seeing in RFID. But the growth organic growth of 2%-plus in the quarter w
componenttext: Thank you, George. Yes, so just the comment around RBIS is, we are pleased with the progress we're making of the transformation, which we are very pleased with our growth that we're seeing in RFID. But the growth organic growth of 2%-plus in the quarter was short of our obviously long-term targets that we have for this business. And then, while it is largely due to the softness in the apparel market, we're looking to grow this business 4% to 5% long term. So I would say that we've met our guidance expectations given what was going on in the apparel market. We're pleased with the progress the team is making on the transformation, and we knew this was going to be a multi-year transformation as well. So yes, there's more. We're continuing to focus on health where can we get less complex simpler, if you will, and more competitive across the entire customer base. So this is something that we will continue to be focused on. And I think it's important to step back and yes, the top line has been less consistent, if you will, but we have continued to grow this business over the last number of years. And regardless of market environment, we have consistently expanded margin over each of the years over the last 5 years, and that's something that we're going to continue to do regardless of the market environment, leveraging our strengths in RFID and external embellishment and our customer relationships across all market segments and our focus on productivity to get more competitive.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Zekauskas with JPMorgan securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey Zekauskas with JPMorgan securities.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you said early in the call that volume growth in Pressure-sensitive was negative in North America in the quarter. My memory is maybe last year, it grew 4% or 5% and the first quarter grew 1% or 2%. Is there a change in trend there, or is this quar
componenttext: I think you said early in the call that volume growth in Pressure-sensitive was negative in North America in the quarter. My memory is maybe last year, it grew 4% or 5% and the first quarter grew 1% or 2%. Is there a change in trend there, or is this quarter an anomaly? What's happening there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the a trends -- so we did have negative growth, slightly negative in this quarter. I would not -- I don't think we've said that this business has been 4% to 5%, I think even last year, we saw a bit of a modest improvement, low single digit growth
componenttext: Yes. So the a trends -- so we did have negative growth, slightly negative in this quarter. I would not -- I don't think we've said that this business has been 4% to 5%, I think even last year, we saw a bit of a modest improvement, low single digit growth in this business. So I think it was in a band. If you go over last several quarters, it's within a pretty tight band of where we're seeing this business. I don't think we're seeing dramatic changes in the marketplace.

componenttext: Okay. You said that there's now a little bit of raw material pressure. So if raw materials are -- I take it that they're going up, or is it that prices are coming down? Where does this squeeze come from? On the price side or on the raw materials side?

componenttext: Jeff, we don't comment on the specific components. We talked about the net -- the modest net headwind, if you will, which is not exceptional by any stretch if you look at the long-term trajectory within the business. So yes, overall, I think this message here is stable in general, stable on raw material inflation, that type of environment we seeing, and we continue to see what you normally expect in a competitive industry like we're in on a top line.

componenttextpreview: They will be higher in the second half. Most of the growth will be in Q3 though. Q4 is particularly a tough comps, so we still expect some modest growth in Q4, but it will be modest. Unless another rollout starts, of course.
componenttext: They will be higher in the second half. Most of the growth will be in Q3 though. Q4 is particularly a tough comps, so we still expect some modest growth in Q4, but it will be modest. Unless another rollout starts, of course.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you said that in Pressure-sensitive, you had inflationary pricing in South America. Did that lead overall to positive pricing for Pressure-sensitive in the quarter or negative pricing?
componenttext: Okay. And you said that in Pressure-sensitive, you had inflationary pricing in South America. Did that lead overall to positive pricing for Pressure-sensitive in the quarter or negative pricing?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Jeff in a number of markets, particular Latin America, we do have what we call currency pricing. So when the currencies move, I think lot of the raw material input costs are coming outside the region. So it's not having a net positive impact overa
componenttext: Yes, so Jeff in a number of markets, particular Latin America, we do have what we call currency pricing. So when the currencies move, I think lot of the raw material input costs are coming outside the region. So it's not having a net positive impact overall to in a sizeable ways to the bottom line. It's just more way to cover the input cost in the local currency.

componenttext: Yes. So that business, we've been talking about being in a turn around and some of the change we started making mid- to late last year around getting more top line pipeline moving again. And so to answer questions specifically, we don't expect that positive margin to stay at that level going into the second half. There will be some headwinds on that front and also on the top line within that business. We expect to take us in the 2017 to kind of see the reverse in this trajectory and the turnaround to that business.

componenttextpreview: And when you look at the customers or the garments that are you using your products on RBIS, can you separate -- I mean, you talked about no growth or decline in the department stores. But could you separate the high-end products garments versus the type
componenttext: And when you look at the customers or the garments that are you using your products on RBIS, can you separate -- I mean, you talked about no growth or decline in the department stores. But could you separate the high-end products garments versus the type of garments that will be sold at Walmart, at Target? Could you give a feel as to what the industry is doing?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Overall, and I think some of it reflects the types of garments, but with the exception of the impact of some inventory reductions that are impacting us in Q2 or impacted us in Q2, performance athletics, for example, high-value athletic garments have
componenttext: Sure. Overall, and I think some of it reflects the types of garments, but with the exception of the impact of some inventory reductions that are impacting us in Q2 or impacted us in Q2, performance athletics, for example, high-value athletic garments have done and are expected to continue to do well. Fast fashion has done quite well in the market, so that's low cost, high churn, a lot of the fashion elements. That has done well and expected to do well the, which is one of the reasons why we are focusing on driving growth with that segment and taking share. Value continues to do well. And value actually has a range of -- value and contemporary a full range of high-end markets and more discount garments so it's hard to call out specifically what's winning within that space overall. But I think what you're seeing here is broad-based. We can even talk about the apartment stores, department stores are a number of them getting -- having some challenges right now and fast fashion is a particular growth driver within the industry.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just last one, quick one, guys. As we think about the guidance for the year, and it went up $0.05, which was basically what the variance was round numbers. In the second quarter, which in turn was driven by Pressure-sensitive Materials. Now, again, I thin
componenttext: Just last one, quick one, guys. As we think about the guidance for the year, and it went up $0.05, which was basically what the variance was round numbers. In the second quarter, which in turn was driven by Pressure-sensitive Materials. Now, again, I think some of other analyst has asked the same question, there are a lot of things that are going right for Pressure-sensitive at the moment, the growth in emerging markets, the mix inherent in those markets and so on, and those recognized seasonally there should be some drop-off, but we wouldn't expect a significant one in the third quarter anyway relative to second quarter based on history. So should we just very simply assume that the only -- the reason you took guidance by the amount that you beat 2Q is that where ever you're seeing improvement in Pressure-sensitive is being largely offset at this juncture by RBIS and Vancive in the back half of the year or will there be nuances around that?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. So in general, if you look at the range of the guidance as we talked about earlier, you would have to assume that you would have higher growth rate in the second half and that you would have to cover for some of the headwinds we got seasonality an
componenttext: Thanks. So in general, if you look at the range of the guidance as we talked about earlier, you would have to assume that you would have higher growth rate in the second half and that you would have to cover for some of the headwinds we got seasonality and don't forget we've got the tape customer business coming out, which is higher margin than the average for the segment and really is sort of the second half as well when we think about the impact of the business. So you do have -- you have to take that [indiscernible] that type headwind. We also have a $0.02 headwind for FX that you will see in the guidance as well.
