headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the RBIS pricing actions, I was wondering if it's possible to say how long you expect those to be a headwind. Do you lap that headwind at the end of the year? Or is it possible that pricing actions may be -- move into 2017? And then kind of relatedly
componenttext:
On the RBIS pricing actions, I was wondering if it's possible to say how long you expect those to be a headwind. Do you lap that headwind at the end of the year? Or is it possible that pricing actions may be -- move into 2017? 
And then kind of relatedly, is it possible to quantify how much market share you've gained back since starting these actions? Or just qualitatively, can you give us any color in terms of how you feel from a market share perspective?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So there's always pressuring actions at various levels. But the specific actions we took late last year, we do cycle through beginning in the second half. So it blends in beginning in Q3 through the end of Q4. So we do cycle through that then. And
componenttext:
Yes. So there's always pressuring actions at various levels. But the specific actions we took late last year, we do cycle through beginning in the second half. So it blends in beginning in Q3 through the end of Q4. So we do cycle through that then. 
And as far as from a share gain perspective, relative to the growth that we're seeing within fast fashion, our growth levels are exceeding the end market, so very confident we're taking share there. From a value perspective, we believe we're taking share within value. And contemporary, so department stores, tough to read. As I commented on, the volumes there or the trends that we're seeing are positive and well -- we're seeing their performance in the marketplace. We believe we are now regaining share there. That was a space, if you recall, along with value, we were losing share on up until beginning late last year, if you will. So we believe we're starting to shift the share mix overall for those businesses, but we'll have to see how their performance plays out here over the next couple of quarters.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. That's helpful. And then on the restructuring costs, the impact to EPS was lower, $0.20 to $0.15, but the savings remain the same. Can you just provide a little bit more color on that? Why is the restructuring program going to cost less than o
componenttext: Okay, okay. That's helpful. And then on the restructuring costs, the impact to EPS was lower, $0.20 to $0.15, but the savings remain the same. Can you just provide a little bit more color on that? Why is the restructuring program going to cost less than originally anticipated? Or what's the progress there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. There was a couple of things that we looked at. First of all, we went in and really trued up our estimates of these costs, and so we saw some -- we were a little conservative, so we trued that up and we see favorability on that. And then quite frankl
componenttext: Yes. There was a couple of things that we looked at. First of all, we went in and really trued up our estimates of these costs, and so we saw some -- we were a little conservative, so we trued that up and we see favorability on that. And then quite frankly, some of this was just some of the timing of when the costs are actually going to be recorded or hit in the year. So we're -- some of that will have a little bit of a timing shift.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So it gets pushed into 2017 or...
componenttext: Okay. So it gets pushed into 2017 or...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, early '17.
componenttext: Yes, early '17.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Louis Gaffner with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Louis Gaffner with Barclays Capital.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, I just wanted to focus again on Pressure-sensitive for a second, just given the margin performance in the quarter. Is it the margin profile of the products that you're selling in the emerging markets is pushing the margin here? Or is it the increme
componenttext: Mitch, I just wanted to focus again on Pressure-sensitive for a second, just given the margin performance in the quarter. Is it the margin profile of the products that you're selling in the emerging markets is pushing the margin here? Or is it the incremental margins on the 10% growth rate? Or how should we think about -- what was really pushing that incremental margin in 2Q?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So broad-based, it's not one specific item we're seeing here. I think the key thing -- this, as I said, exceeded our expectations, even the high end of our expectations for the quarter. The biggest single driver was the variable flow-through of the a
componenttext: Yes. So broad-based, it's not one specific item we're seeing here. I think the key thing -- this, as I said, exceeded our expectations, even the high end of our expectations for the quarter. The biggest single driver was the variable flow-through of the additional volume that we saw. The growth rate within PSM was above, if you will, the margin -- I mean, the guidance range we have for the whole business for the year, and it definitely was a little bit higher than we expected, particularly coming out of Europe. So that was a key driver overall, Scott, for the PSM performance in Q2.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And Anne, I think you mentioned, though, that price cost was negative. Do you expect that to continue for a couple of quarters within the segment?
componenttext: Okay. And Anne, I think you mentioned, though, that price cost was negative. Do you expect that to continue for a couple of quarters within the segment?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we were talking about this for -- as you know, for a while. And we -- over the cycle, you would normally see that you're -- you would see a negative impact of price cost. And so we're going to call that out, that we are seeing a modest impact this
componenttext: Yes. So we were talking about this for -- as you know, for a while. And we -- over the cycle, you would normally see that you're -- you would see a negative impact of price cost. And so we're going to call that out, that we are seeing a modest impact this quarter. And you will expect to see over a cycle that, that will continue.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just on the growth in the business in the emerging markets, Mitch, you mentioned Southeast Asia, India. What's -- what are the product categories that are really growing? I mean, even in Latin America, you had solid growth. Is it more on variabl
componenttext: Okay. And just on the growth in the business in the emerging markets, Mitch, you mentioned Southeast Asia, India. What's -- what are the product categories that are really growing? I mean, even in Latin America, you had solid growth. Is it more on variable information side of the business? Is it on the consumer products side? What -- where are you seeing the growth? Where is that coming from?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's broad-based. But just this -- the whole -- I mean, the economy in South Asia, both Southeast Asia as well as India, are doing quite well, and you continue to see expanded consumer spending. So it's consumer products linked as well as variable informa
componenttext: It's broad-based. But just this -- the whole -- I mean, the economy in South Asia, both Southeast Asia as well as India, are doing quite well, and you continue to see expanded consumer spending. So it's consumer products linked as well as variable information labels as well, and it's very broad-based. And I said it's a very healthy double-digit growth there. I just got back from a 3-week trip over in Asia. And I'll tell you, just -- when you're engaging with customers and so forth, they're quite optimistic about the prospects for their countries and their individual industries and excited about what's going to come. And they -- we are key partners for them not only helping ourselves, but helping them growth and lead the market to GDP-plus type of growth.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good to hear. Just one last one for me on RBIS and I guess, RFID, in particular. I think you said you expected it would be up 30% at the current run rate. How big would that make the RFID business for you if you actually achieved a 30% rate? And th
componenttext: That's good to hear. Just one last one for me on RBIS and I guess, RFID, in particular. I think you said you expected it would be up 30% at the current run rate. How big would that make the RFID business for you if you actually achieved a 30% rate? And then in addition to that, how have the recent rollouts been going? Have you seen any customers interested in moving from test to broad-based rollout? Can you just give an update there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So the business after this year will be roughly $200 million for the full year, so pretty sizable relative to the total size of RBIS. And I think this is an important thing to point out. If you look at RFID and our external embellishment, it's rough
componenttext: Sure. So the business after this year will be roughly $200 million for the full year, so pretty sizable relative to the total size of RBIS. And I think this is an important thing to point out. If you look at RFID and our external embellishment, it's roughly 15% of total RBIS right now, where it was 6% just 5 years ago. And for the whole theme we're talking about continuing to improve our portfolio mix and higher-value product lines. That's a great example of what's going on within RBIS as well. So there's a number -- we don't talk about specific customers within RFID and who's going to full rollout and so forth. But I will tell you, the pipeline is rich. We've got about 90 customers in the total pipeline, a blend between those that are in full adoption, those that are in rollout, those that are in pilot, and those are at the very early stages of just evaluating the business case. So continue to see great progress. And we -- as I said before, we are -- we do have the go-to team for RFID adoption, and that's something that we -- a leadership position we expect to maintain.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Christopher John Kapsch with BB&T Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Christopher John Kapsch with BB&T Capital Markets.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a couple follow-ups. Just wondering if you could explain why you suppose China was flat vis--vis the growth that you're seeing in other emerging markets. Is there a different competitive dynamic there versus other regions? I know Raflatac did add
componenttext: I had a couple follow-ups. Just wondering if you could explain why you suppose China was flat vis--vis the growth that you're seeing in other emerging markets. Is there a different competitive dynamic there versus other regions? I know Raflatac did add some capacity over there not too long ago.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to pinpoint to any one thing. I will tell you, when I was over there speaking with customers, generally, they're talking about the challenge of just a little bit low -- adjusting to a lower growth environment right now. We do expect this busines
componenttext: It's hard to pinpoint to any one thing. I will tell you, when I was over there speaking with customers, generally, they're talking about the challenge of just a little bit low -- adjusting to a lower growth environment right now. We do expect this business to continue to grow and China to be a mid-single-digit growth market, which we still consider a very healthy clip. And so you're seeing a little bit of adjustments down from, I'd say, that industry used to growth closer to 10% and being mid-single digits. Specifically, within the quarter, there was a number of puts and takes for being depressed down to the low single digits or roughly flat, but no key takeaways right now. And I will say, for our business, a single quarter of being flat to growing a few percent, that can happen. Our expectation here is mid-single digits for China.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just moving sort of western around the world to Europe. Just wondering if -- I mean, the trends there have continued to -- pretty buoyant considering what's gone out over there. And I'm just curious if there's been any change in those trend
componenttext: Okay. And then just moving sort of western around the world to Europe. Just wondering if -- I mean, the trends there have continued to -- pretty buoyant considering what's gone out over there. And I'm just curious if there's been any change in those trends since the Brexit vote, I guess, around a month ago.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually too early to tell overall, is what I'd say. Clearly, I think the broader question is just what does it mean for the EU and so forth. But if you look at where we are, our market leadership position regardless of market environment, we are wel
componenttext: It's actually too early to tell overall, is what I'd say. Clearly, I think the broader question is just what does it mean for the EU and so forth. But if you look at where we are, our market leadership position regardless of market environment, we are well positioned for this. And the U.K. business is just a little over $100 million worth of business, so relatively small in the grand scheme of things. Personally, I think it's a little bit blown out of proportion, a little bit some of the market reaction initially with what we saw. But we're well positioned. And if there's some challenges in the marketplace, we're going to be looking to take advantage of those as the market leader.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And if I could just follow up on this Pressure-sensitive segment margin topic. And I know you kind of referred to first quarter performance, which was strong, as possibly approaching peak and now we exceeded that performance by 60 basis points seque
componenttext: Okay. And if I could just follow up on this Pressure-sensitive segment margin topic. And I know you kind of referred to first quarter performance, which was strong, as possibly approaching peak and now we exceeded that performance by 60 basis points sequentially. And it sounds as though like mix is -- obviously, operational excellence is contributing, but also mix with the growth that you've seen in international markets, which, I believe, are higher margin and obviously, your emphasis on shifting towards the more value-added products. And it sounds like that's all going to continue, particularly with investment in accelerating the growth of those sorts of product lines. So just wondering, given how well you're executing and given the trajectory of those higher-margin businesses, what -- just what's maybe a more realistic longer-term margin expectation for this Pressure-sensitive segment as we continue to move forward here?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we're not resetting margin targets right now. We've said that this business, at the margins that we've had, even 11% plus, very healthy returns. And our focus is, again, finding the right balance with top line growth margins and capital efficiency
componenttext: Yes. So we're not resetting margin targets right now. We've said that this business, at the margins that we've had, even 11% plus, very healthy returns. And our focus is, again, finding the right balance with top line growth margins and capital efficiency to optimize EVA. So we will be setting new targets when we come out. We're going to do an Investor Day. We're now planning for that to be in March. And we will send out a press release with the exact date here in due time. But that will be the time that we reset it. And again, I want to emphasize here, the previous targets we had, we a clearly don't feel limited by those in any way. We are going to continue driving forward and finding that optimum balance. And we've, again, expanded margin by 300 basis points over the last few years. And that, remember, we've got questions about resetting targets a year -- beginning 1.5 years ago. Had we set them then, we probably would be talking about should we be resetting them again right now, given where our performance is. So we are testing new heights and will continue to do so, and we'll update everybody with our long-term expectations in March.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Well -- and just one quick follow-up. And you'll continue to get the question until you do reset the margins, I'm thinking, but I'm -- the...
componenttext: Right. Well -- and just one quick follow-up. And you'll continue to get the question until you do reset the margins, I'm thinking, but I'm -- the...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood.
componenttext: Understood.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if your -- are you constrained -- given the margin performance and how this business has done, are you constrained anywhere, where you feel like you need to ramp up capital in order to capitalize on growth in the Pressure-sensitive division
componenttext: Just wondering if your -- are you constrained -- given the margin performance and how this business has done, are you constrained anywhere, where you feel like you need to ramp up capital in order to capitalize on growth in the Pressure-sensitive division?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I wouldn't say constrained, but we have said that we are going to be increasing the pace of capital investment within this business. If you look at the growth rate, to your point, we do need to increase the pace of capital investment. That is somethi
componenttext: Yes. I wouldn't say constrained, but we have said that we are going to be increasing the pace of capital investment within this business. If you look at the growth rate, to your point, we do need to increase the pace of capital investment. That is something we would expect. If you look at the long-term targets that we had laid out a couple years ago, it was roughly an average of a couple hundred million dollars over the horizon. We haven't been on that pace until now, but we do expect to be ramping up here, specifically, to capture profitable growth, to your point.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Leon Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Leon Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, the first question I had, and we're beating the Pressure-sensitive margin question into the ground, but would you expect from the current level in the second quarter that you achieved that we should be seeing some flattening out from here seasona
componenttext: I guess, the first question I had, and we're beating the Pressure-sensitive margin question into the ground, but would you expect from the current level in the second quarter that you achieved that we should be seeing some flattening out from here seasonally? Or is that getting too close for comfort and the commentary about 1Q being perhaps close to peak maybe created more distraction than needed to be and we should just let you run your business and wherever the margins come out, they come out?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, personally, I like that second option, but I guess, I'll have to address the first question. So look, as I talked about, we -- even the in last quarter's call and this quarter's call, we are hitting new heights, as we talked about. We do have season
componenttext: Well, personally, I like that second option, but I guess, I'll have to address the first question. So look, as I talked about, we -- even the in last quarter's call and this quarter's call, we are hitting new heights, as we talked about. We do have seasonality in this business, and I think you've seen that historically. Traditionally, Q4, in particular, has quite a dip in margin when you look at the historical trend on this. I would say that -- and as I mentioned, we also have the headwind at the Performance Tapes customer in the second half. So we -- when you look at the high end of the range, you would have to assume that we can largely sustain this and overcome some other -- some of these issues as well. But at the high end, it's really sustaining this, but continuing it through and overcoming some of the Performance Tapes customer loss.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So George, just to reinforce what Anne said, we typically see a drop in Q4 by a full point. And then we've talked about tapes, the decline there on the volume side, well, that is a high-margin business, and so that will have a pretty decent impact on
componenttext: Yes. So George, just to reinforce what Anne said, we typically see a drop in Q4 by a full point. And then we've talked about tapes, the decline there on the volume side, well, that is a high-margin business, and so that will have a pretty decent impact on the margins as well. And as Anne said, full range of our guidance, we think, captures the full range of possible -- not possible outcomes, but probable outcomes. And the high end has roughly a continuation, excluding a little bit of the excess in Q2, if you will, but a continuation of margin trends we saw in Q -- first half continuing into the second half with a normal seasonal drop and the impact of Performance Tapes.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I appreciate that additional color. That helps us here. If we talk about RFID. So I remember from the last quarter you were expecting 20% growth thereabouts. And now you're in excess of 30%, so I think a lot of the answer here is in relation to what
componenttext: Okay. I appreciate that additional color. That helps us here. If we talk about RFID. So I remember from the last quarter you were expecting 20% growth thereabouts. And now you're in excess of 30%, so I think a lot of the answer here is in relation to what you're saying to, I think, Scott's question about RFID. But have you seen more customers coming to you for trials as the reason for the increase in the growth rate? Or has it been a greater amount of sale in existing trials that's been driving the increase in the guidance there for the full year? Obviously, you have tougher comps in the second half.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Generally, the latter. So it's an increase in sales to customers that are already in the process of rolling out. So just being more aggressive, if you will, the customers in their rollout. So that's been the primary driver. As far as customers switching i
componenttext: Generally, the latter. So it's an increase in sales to customers that are already in the process of rolling out. So just being more aggressive, if you will, the customers in their rollout. So that's been the primary driver. As far as customers switching into full adoption, if you will, or into rollout, that's something that -- usually, there's a pretty short lead time from when that's announced to when we start sourcing that. So the key question here, we talked a little bit of tough comps in Q4 -- the question here will anybody else to convert to that next level, which we've seen in the past, as you know.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. The last question I had, and I'll turn it over because most of my questions have already been asked. When we look at RBIS -- and I think you said you're ultimately constructive or pleased with where the business is. And I'm putting words in yo
componenttext: Understood. The last question I had, and I'll turn it over because most of my questions have already been asked. When we look at RBIS -- and I think you said you're ultimately constructive or pleased with where the business is. And I'm putting words in your mouth, so feel free to adapt as you need to. But when I look at the margin -- or the margin dollars year-on-year being flat versus 2Q, in spite of the $60 million net benefit that, that segment is getting from restructuring and other performance improvements, are you really happy with that business? Should we assume that all of that benefit has been basically used to grow market share through pricing and other actions? And should we expect a continuation of the playbook and maybe even an intensification of the strategies in that playbook to ultimately try to grow volume and margin for the segment in the next 12 to 18 months?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, George. Yes, so just the comment around RBIS is we're pleased with the progress we're making on the transformation, which we are very pleased with our growth that we're seeing in RFID. But that the growth, organic growth of 2% plus in the quart
componenttext: Thank you, George. Yes, so just the comment around RBIS is we're pleased with the progress we're making on the transformation, which we are very pleased with our growth that we're seeing in RFID. But that the growth, organic growth of 2% plus in the quarter was short of our, obviously, long-term targets that we have for this business. And while it is largely due to the softness in the apparel market, we're looking to grow this business 4% to 5% long term. So I would say that we met our guidance expectations, given what was going on in the apparel market. We're pleased with the progress the team is making on the transformation, and we knew this was going to be a multiyear transformation as well. So yes, there's more. We're continuing to focus on how, where can we get less complex, simpler, if you will, and more competitive across the entire customer base. So this is something that we will continue to be focused on. And I think it's important as you step back. I mean, yes, the top line has been less consistent, if you will, but we have continued to grow this business over the last number of years. And regardless of market environment, we have consistently expanded margin over -- each of the years over the last 5 years. And that's something that we're going to continue to do regardless of the market environment, leveraging our strengths in RFID and external embellishments and our customer relationships across all market segments and our focus on productivity to get more competitive.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey John Zekauskas with JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Jeffrey John Zekauskas with JPMorgan Securities.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you said early in the call that volume growth in Pressure-sensitive was negative in North America in the quarter. My memory is maybe last year, it grew 4% or 5%, and the first quarter grew 1% or 2%. Is there a change in trend there? Or is this qua
componenttext: I think you said early in the call that volume growth in Pressure-sensitive was negative in North America in the quarter. My memory is maybe last year, it grew 4% or 5%, and the first quarter grew 1% or 2%. Is there a change in trend there? Or is this quarter an anomaly? What's happening there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So the trends -- so we did have negative growth -- slightly negative in this quarter. I would not -- I don't think we've said that this business has been 4% to 5%. I think even last year, we saw a bit of a modest improvement, low single-digit growth
componenttext: Yes. So the trends -- so we did have negative growth -- slightly negative in this quarter. I would not -- I don't think we've said that this business has been 4% to 5%. I think even last year, we saw a bit of a modest improvement, low single-digit growth in this business. So I think it within a band -- if you go over the last several quarters, it's within a pretty tight band of where we're seeing this business. I don't think you're seeing dramatic changes in the marketplace.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. You said that there's now a little bit of raw material pressure. So if raw materials are -- I take it that they're going up. Or is it that prices are coming down? Where does the squeeze come from? On the price side or on the raw materials side?
componenttext: Okay. You said that there's now a little bit of raw material pressure. So if raw materials are -- I take it that they're going up. Or is it that prices are coming down? Where does the squeeze come from? On the price side or on the raw materials side?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Jeff, we don't comment on the specific components. We talk about the net -- a modest net headwind, if you will, which is not exceptional by any stretch if you look at the long-term trajectory within the business. So -- yes. So overall, I think the
componenttext: Yes. So Jeff, we don't comment on the specific components. We talk about the net -- a modest net headwind, if you will, which is not exceptional by any stretch if you look at the long-term trajectory within the business. So -- yes. So overall, I think the message here is stable on -- in general, stable on raw material inflation. That's the type of environment we're seeing, and we continue to see what you'd normally expect in a competitive industry like we're in on the top line.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, in terms of your upcoming acquisition, do you have all of the regulatory approvals for it?
componenttext: Okay. Well, in terms of your upcoming acquisition, do you have all of the regulatory approvals for it?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Jeff, just received word this morning, actually, that we received final regulatory approval. We expected that to come through, which is why we said we expect to close in August. But that did actually come through this morning, so we are still on t
componenttext: Yes. So Jeff, just received word this morning, actually, that we received final regulatory approval. We expected that to come through, which is why we said we expect to close in August. But that did actually come through this morning, so we are still on track and expect to be closing here in the coming weeks.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Will RFID revenues be higher or lower in the second half than in the first half given that you grew 50% in the second quarter and you expect to grow 30% for the year?
componenttext: Okay. Will RFID revenues be higher or lower in the second half than in the first half given that you grew 50% in the second quarter and you expect to grow 30% for the year?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: They will be higher in the second half. Most of the growth will be in Q3, though. Q4 is particularly where the tough comps are. We still expect some modest growth in Q4, but it will be modest, unless another rollout starts, of course.
componenttext: They will be higher in the second half. Most of the growth will be in Q3, though. Q4 is particularly where the tough comps are. We still expect some modest growth in Q4, but it will be modest, unless another rollout starts, of course.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you said that in Pressure-sensitive, you had inflationary pricing in South America. Did that lead overall to positive pricing for the -- for Pressure-sensitive in the quarter or negative pricing?
componenttext: Okay. And you said that in Pressure-sensitive, you had inflationary pricing in South America. Did that lead overall to positive pricing for the -- for Pressure-sensitive in the quarter or negative pricing?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Jeff, in a number of markets, particularly Latin America, we do have what we call currency pricing. So when the currencies move -- because a lot of the raw material input costs are coming from outside the region. So it's not having a net positive
componenttext: Yes. So Jeff, in a number of markets, particularly Latin America, we do have what we call currency pricing. So when the currencies move -- because a lot of the raw material input costs are coming from outside the region. So it's not having a net positive impact overall to -- in a sizeable way to the bottom line. It's just more way to cover the input costs in the local currency.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Rosemarie Morbelli with Gabelli & Company.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Rosemarie Morbelli with Gabelli & Company.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was -- most of my questions have been answered, but there is one little hole regarding Vancive. Could you give us a little more details on that particular business? Is that $1.6 million of EBIT sustainable over the balance of the year, and then we start
componenttext: I was -- most of my questions have been answered, but there is one little hole regarding Vancive. Could you give us a little more details on that particular business? Is that $1.6 million of EBIT sustainable over the balance of the year, and then we start seeing the -- a substantial margin improvement the next year?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So that business, we've been talking about being in a turnaround. And some of the change we started making mid- to late last year around getting the -- more top line pipeline moving again. And so to answer your question specifically, we don't expect
componenttext: Yes. So that business, we've been talking about being in a turnaround. And some of the change we started making mid- to late last year around getting the -- more top line pipeline moving again. And so to answer your question specifically, we don't expect the positive margins to stay at that level going into the second half. There will be some headwinds on that front and also on the top line within that business. We expect it to take us into 2017 to kind of see that reverse in this trajectory and the turnaround of that business.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Overall -- and I think it's somewhat reflective of the types of garments, but with the exception of the impact of some inventory reductions that are impacting us in Q2 -- or impacted us in Q2, performance athletics, for example, high-value athletic
componenttext: Sure. Overall -- and I think it's somewhat reflective of the types of garments, but with the exception of the impact of some inventory reductions that are impacting us in Q2 -- or impacted us in Q2, performance athletics, for example, high-value athletic garments have done and are expected to continue to do well. Fast fashion has done quite well in the market. So that's the low-cost, high-churn, a lot of fashion elements. That has done well and is expected to continue to do well, which is one of the reasons why we are focusing on driving growth with that segment and taking share. Value continues to do well. And value, actually, has a range of -- value and contemporary, a full range of high-end garments and more discount garments, so it's hard to call out specifically what's winning within that space overall. But I think what you're seeing here is broad-based. Or we can even talk about the department stores. Department stores are, a number of them, getting -- having some challenges right now, and fast fashion is a particular growth driver within the industry.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just last one, quick one, guys. As we think about the guidance for the year, and it went up $0.05, which was basically what the variance was, round numbers, in the second quarter, which in turn was driven by Pressure-sensitive Materials. Now again, I thin
componenttext: Just last one, quick one, guys. As we think about the guidance for the year, and it went up $0.05, which was basically what the variance was, round numbers, in the second quarter, which in turn was driven by Pressure-sensitive Materials. Now again, I think some of other analysts have asked the same question. There are lots of things that are going right for Pressure-sensitive at the moment, the growth in emerging markets, the mix inherent in those markets and so on. And those -- I recognize seasonally there should be some drop-off, but we wouldn't expect a significant one in the third quarter, anyway, relative to second quarter based on history. So should we just very simply assume that the only -- the reason you only took your guidance up by the amount that you beat 2Q is that whatever you're seeing in improvement in Pressure-sensitive is being largely offset at this juncture by RBIS and Vancive at the back half of the year? Or would there be any nuances around that?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in general, if you look at the range of the guidance, as we talked about earlier, you would have to assume that you would have higher growth rates in the second half and that you would have to cover for some of the headwinds we've got for seasonality.
componenttext: So in general, if you look at the range of the guidance, as we talked about earlier, you would have to assume that you would have higher growth rates in the second half and that you would have to cover for some of the headwinds we've got for seasonality. And then don't forget we've got the tapes customer business coming out, which is higher-margin than the average for the segment and really has distorted the second half as well when we think about the impact to the business. So you do have -- you have to take into account the Vancive, the RBIS and then the fact that we've got those headwinds. We also have a $0.02 headwind for FX that you will see in the guidance as well.

componenttext:
Yes, thank you. So overall, we're pleased with the quarter and pleased with the progress we're making across both of our strategic and financial priorities. We remain committed to achieving our long-term targets by driving accelerated growth in our high-value segments and continuing to leverage our strength traditionally in productivity to ensure we can continue to have healthy returns and expanding margins across all product categories. 
And I want to thank the leadership team and employees everywhere for their hard work, creativity and commitment to our success. So thank you.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the third quarter ended October 1, 2016. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 10:00 a.m. Pacific time today through midn
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the third quarter ended October 1, 2016. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 10:00 a.m. Pacific time today through midnight Pacific time October 29. To access the replay, please dial (800) 633-8284 or (402) 977-9140 for international callers. The conference ID number is 21782908. [Operator Instructions] 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Cindy Guenther, Avery Dennison's Vice President of Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dmitra. Today, we'll discuss our preliminary unaudited third quarter results. The non-GAAP financial measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP on Schedules A-4 to A-8 of the financial statements accompanying today's e
componenttext:
Thank you, Dmitra. Today, we'll discuss our preliminary unaudited third quarter results. The non-GAAP financial measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP on Schedules A-4 to A-8 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release. We remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These forward-looking statements are made subject to the safe harbor statement included in today's earnings release.
On the call today are Mitch Butier, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Anne Bramman, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
I'll now turn the call over to Mitch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good day, everyone. We had another quarter of strong earnings growth with EPS above our expectations.We are improving our competitiveness with continued strong profitability across the PSM portfolio and making progress with our busine
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good day, everyone. We had another quarter of strong earnings growth with EPS above our expectations.
We are improving our competitiveness with continued strong profitability across the PSM portfolio and making progress with our business model transformation in RBIS.
As expected, organic sales growth in Pressure-sensitive Materials moderated in the third quarter to 3%, reflecting the program loss in the personal care segment of Performance Tapes that we've discussed previously. Excluding this program loss, sales grew 4.5% organically.
Once again, emerging markets were the key growth driver for PSM, more than offsetting softness in the North American market. From a product perspective, the base label materials business remained healthy with solid top line growth overall and margins expanding across most categories. Graphics and specialty label materials were up high single-digits for the quarter on a global basis. I'm pleased with our progress in shifting PSM's portfolio mix towards these higher value categories. We expect continued benefit over the long term from our focus and investment in these areas. Speaking of which, the integration of our acquisition of the Mactac graphics and tapes business, which we completed in August is going smoothly. We also completed a very small acquisition of Ink Mill during the quarter, which expands our capabilities in the high-value reflectives business. And earlier this month, we made an equity investment in the U.K.-based startup called PragmatIC, leveraging our strength in RFID to enable long-term growth of intelligent labels in new segments. 
All 3 of these recent deals exemplify the range of opportunities we have identified and continue to pursue within our M&A pipeline, with a focus on high-value product lines and supporting technologies.
Our commitment to investing here in terms of both M&A and higher capital spending is reinforced by the excellent progress we've made with the high-value segments through which we have delivered consistent organic growth, improved mix and strong profitability and returns.
Shifting now to Retail Branding and Information Solutions. Sales were up a little over 2% organically driven by Radio Frequency Identification. RFID sales were up over 35% in Q3 and are expected to exceed 30% for the full year. While the pace of growth was slow in the fourth quarter, reflecting the difficult comparison the prior year that we've discussed, we expect the RFID will continue to be a key growth driver for us.
We are continuing to invest in this high-value product line, expanding capacity and improving our manufacturing processes as well as participating in promising new ventures like PragmatIC.
Outside of RFID, top line growth was short of our target for the quarter amidst a difficult retail apparel market in the U.S. particularly among the department stores.
That said, we saw solid volume gains across the base business, representing clear signs of success for our multiyear transformation strategy as we become faster, simpler and more competitive while driving margin expansion.
Our strategy is the right one. Moving decision-making closer to our markets, reducing complexity as well as our cost structure and qualifying lower-cost, locally sourced materials to support more competitive pricing.
Our improvements in service, flexibility and speed are resonating with customers. In light of the soft top line though, these actions have not been enough to deliver the margin expansion we had targeted for the year. Now we will accelerate our efforts through 2017 to further improve our competitiveness and achieve our 2018 margin expansion target.
So coming back to the total company view. Overall, we've made good progress against our strategic and financial objectives as evidenced by another solid quarter and a $0.10 increase to expected EPS for the year.
We remain highly confident in our ability to consistently deliver exceptional value over the long run based on the execution of our key strategies. First and foremost, we will drive outsized growth in high-value segments. We will continue to invest disproportionately here both organically and through bolt-on acquisitions.  Over time, this will improve our portfolio mix and bolster our leadership in these key segments.
Second, we are relentless in our pursuit of productivity improvement to enhance our competitiveness across all product categories and, of course, to drive margin expansion.
And third, we are maintaining our high degree of capital efficiency while increasing investments to support profitable growth and, of course, we will continue our disciplined approach to returning cash to shareholders.
Now I will turn the call over to Anne.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mitch. Providing a little more color on the quarter. In Q3, we delivered a 16% increase in adjusted earnings per share on 3% organic sales growth. Currency translation reduced reported sales by 1.7% in the third quarter, which was offset by the li
componenttext:
Thanks, Mitch. Providing a little more color on the quarter. In Q3, we delivered a 16% increase in adjusted earnings per share on 3% organic sales growth. Currency translation reduced reported sales by 1.7% in the third quarter, which was offset by the lift from the Mactac acquisition.
Adjusted operating margin in the third quarter improved 40 basis points to 9.8% as the benefit of productivity initiatives and higher volume more than offset higher employee-related expenses and the net impact of price and raw material input cost. We realized about $21 million of incremental savings from restructuring charges net of transition costs. The adjusted tax rate for the quarter was 31%, reflecting a reduction to our estimate for the full year effective tax rate from 34% at the end of Q2 to 33% due to stronger income growth and lower tax jurisdictions.
Year-to-date, free cash flow was $248 million, an increase of $57 million compared to last year. During the first 9 months of the year, we repurchased approximately 2.7 million shares and paid $106 million in dividends. Net of dilution, we reduced our share count by approximately 1 million shares for a net cost of $118 million, bringing the total amount of cash returned to shareholders so far this year to roughly $224 million. Our balance sheet remained strong, and we have ample capacity to continue funding acquisitions as well as returning cash to shareholders in a disciplined manner.
We funded the acquisition of Mactac Europe through euro-denominated commercial paper. We will explore a euro-denominated debt offering in the first half of next year to refinance notes that will be maturing later in 2017 as well as the Mactac acquisition. Our objective will be to take advantage of the low interest rates in Europe and the opportunity to hedge currency exposure on our balance sheet. 
Now looking at the segments. Pressure-sensitive Materials sales were up approximately 3% on an organic basis. Emerging markets continue to be strong contributors to growth through the segment, representing virtually all of the top line growth in the third quarter. Excluding the impact of the program loss in Performance Tapes, emerging market sales were up over 10% organically comparable to the pace we saw in the second quarter. This strength was fairly widespread across the countries that comprise emerging markets. Of particular note, the underlying growth trend in China picked up modestly compared to the second quarter. You may recall that sales in China were roughly flat in Q2 on an organic basis. Adjusting for holiday timing and the tapes loss, we estimate the underlying organic sales growth for China was back to the low single digit rate we saw in the first quarter of this year and for 2015 as a whole. 
Turning to the mature markets. In North America, sales declined at a low single-digit rate on an organic basis. This reflects a soft market and the pass-through of savings from deflation, while Western Europe was up low single-digits. Demand in Western Europe has been consistently growing at solid low- to mid-single digit rates and on occasion even higher.  Factoring in Eastern Europe, the overall European market has been a strong source of growth for us and we expect that strength to continue.
We are investing to keep pace with the growth in this region, recently announcing a $65 million investment over the next 1.5 years to expand both the capabilities and capacity of our flagship operation in Luxembourg. From a product line perspective, Label and Packaging Materials sales were up mid-single digits organically, while sales for the combined Graphics and Performance Tapes product lines were down low single-digits reflecting the expected program loss for tapes.
Excluding the program loss, combined sales for Graphics and Performance Tapes were up mid-single digits on an organic basis.
Pressure-sensitive Materials adjusted operating margin of 12.6% was up 50 basis points over last year as the benefits from productivity and higher volume more than offset the net impact of price and raw material input cost as well as unfavorable mix. 
Shifting now to Retail Branding and Information Solutions. RBIS sales grew 2% on an organic basis driven by growth of RFID.  Sales outside of RFID continue to be soft down low single digits, reflecting modest growth in volume, which was more than offset by the impact of strategic pricing actions that we began taking late last year.
As you know, we began adjusting our prices in late 2015 to become more competitive, so the sales growth comparisons for the base business become modestly easier in the fourth quarter. As Mitch said, we do believe that the transformation of our business model becoming more cost and price competitive while providing better and faster service is driving volume growth albeit in a challenging retail apparel environment that makes it tough to see the impact of these wins in our financial results.
From a regional perspective, we saw strong mid-single-digit unit point growth for core Label products among European retailers and brand owners due in part to continued progress in expanding our share among the fast fashion players.
Unit volumes for core products were flat in the U.S, an improvement over the mid-single-digit decline we saw last quarter. This market is especially challenged as demonstrated by macro indicators.  In particular, apparel imports into the U.S. were down on average by about 3% for the most recent 3 months reported. And since the fourth quarter of last year, the inventory to sales ratio for U.S. apparel has been at prerecession level. Adjusted operating margin for the segment improved by 20 basis points as the net savings from the business model transformation was largely offset by higher employee-related costs. We have not changed our long-term margin expansion objectives for this business and expect to achieve the goal we set for 2018.
As expected, sales for Vancive Medical Technologies were down 20% on an organic basis in the quarter, reflecting the combined effect of share losses and customer inventory reductions. We were able to partially offset the impact of the sales loss through cost-reduction actions.  Going forward, the steps we began taking mid last year should enable consistent growth and significant margin expansion over the long term. 
Now turning to our outlook for the rest of the year. We have raised the midpoint of the range of our guidance for full year adjusted earnings per share by $0.10 to $3.95 to $4. This reflects the better-than-expected operating results that we delivered in the third quarter, including the lower expected tax rate.
We outlined some of the key contributing factors to our EPS guidance on Slide 8 of our supplemental presentation material.
Highlighting the changes from our previous expectations, we have reduced the high end of our organic growth outlook and now expect full year sales to grow between 3% and 3.5% on an organic basis.
We now expect more than $75 million from restructuring savings net of transition cost for the year. And as discussed previously, we now expect an effective tax rate of approximately 33%.
So just wrapping up, we're very pleased with the strategic and financial progress made against our 2018 goals this past quarter. We're confident we can continue to deliver exceptional value over the long term through superior execution of our strategies, including the disciplined allocation of capital. Now we'll open the call up for your questions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: First off, did you see any measurable change in core sales growth for PSM in any particular month during 3Q? There been some companies and different industries that have commented on the slowdown in Europe in the quarter, wondering if you saw any deviation in the quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so we do normally see some variation month-to-month. We did see a little bit of a slide during Q3 over in Europe. Having said that, we're seeing a little bit of an uptick in early October as well within Europe as well as North America. So I don't re
componenttext: Well, so we do normally see some variation month-to-month. We did see a little bit of a slide during Q3 over in Europe. Having said that, we're seeing a little bit of an uptick in early October as well within Europe as well as North America. So I don't read too much into individual month trends too closely because it's not unusual for us to see 4 weeks of strong performance followed by a softening or vice versa.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then what exactly, Mitch, is do you think driving the weakness in North American PSM? Is that just sort of inventory reductions? What do you think is going on by channel there?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then what exactly, Mitch, is do you think driving the weakness in North American PSM? Is that just sort of inventory reductions? What do you think is going on by channel there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to say. We think there's been a softening in the end consumption of the market in Q3, but we don't have that data right now. But we also did cede some share earlier in the year within that business as we're driving more discipline on the lower v
componenttext: It's hard to say. We think there's been a softening in the end consumption of the market in Q3, but we don't have that data right now. But we also did cede some share earlier in the year within that business as we're driving more discipline on the lower value less differentiated segments. But in the quarter, we think this -- it basically softened a bit. We don't have clear reasons why. At Labelexpo, the sentiment from North American converters was overall I'd say, most of them were very confident in their individual businesses, cautious about the market overall. But also talked about how they themselves, have less visibility to their own order volumes than they traditionally have had as well. So it's hard to give you a read on exactly what's going on in the North American business. Clearly, some of the decline was from Graphics, if you will, within that region specifically. But it's hard to give you a clear read here. As I said, first few weeks of October, we're starting to see an uptick.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just one final one for me. You also called out higher raw material cost for 3Q, can you fexpand on that? And then also, how you kind of position the company for what could be an increase in inflation as we head into 2017 coming off a period of a
componenttext: Okay, and just one final one for me. You also called out higher raw material cost for 3Q, can you fexpand on that? And then also, how you kind of position the company for what could be an increase in inflation as we head into 2017 coming off a period of a few quarters anyway of deflation?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. so we really said was that we saw the an impact to our margins of price net of raw material input cost. And so relatively speaking, we don't get specific color on pricing inflation that as we have been pretty consistent in saying that we broadly have
componenttext: Yes. so we really said was that we saw the an impact to our margins of price net of raw material input cost. And so relatively speaking, we don't get specific color on pricing inflation that as we have been pretty consistent in saying that we broadly have given some price reductions where we have relatively higher variable viable margins we may have seen some deflation. And we basically then passing on to customers some targeted areas and in my script, specifically called out that we've seen that impact in North America.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, just wanted to go back to RBIS for a second. You mentioned the North American apparel retailers and some of the impropriate data. Are there any categories in particular within that channel that you're seeing any weakness in and then what about Euro
componenttext: Mitch, just wanted to go back to RBIS for a second. You mentioned the North American apparel retailers and some of the impropriate data. Are there any categories in particular within that channel that you're seeing any weakness in and then what about European retailers? If you could just give some color there as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the categories within the U.S. department stores in particular, are seeing softness, and we're seeing that as well with our key customers in that space. But generally, I think it's relatively broad-based in the data that Anne shared is across the
componenttext: Yes, so the categories within the U.S. department stores in particular, are seeing softness, and we're seeing that as well with our key customers in that space. But generally, I think it's relatively broad-based in the data that Anne shared is across the entire retail apparel sector, if you will. So inventory levels, return to back this year to their prerecession high. If you recall for a few years after the recession, they were quite a bit lower. Those have balked up. A good portion of that relates to the fact that it was a very warm winter last year and just there was not as much as sell-through as we have been holding on the inventory. So I know the goals for retailers to flush them inventory out of the system through this holiday season. And then for Europe, it depends are overall also softness in the U.K. Clearly, the U.K. retailers with Brexit going on, I think, are struggling a bit. So that's 1 place we see softness. But in Germany, pretty solid. Other markets, we're seeing relatively solid performance at the end retail level.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any you said RFID up 30% in the quarter. With some of the weakness in apparel, are there any change in the conversation with your customers around rates on RFID?
componenttext: Okay. And any you said RFID up 30% in the quarter. With some of the weakness in apparel, are there any change in the conversation with your customers around rates on RFID?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it was up 35% in the quarter, and we expect to be 30% for the full year, expecting the growth to moderate a bit going into -- quite a bit going into Q4. The conversation is very similar. Working through in each retailer, brand needs to go through
componenttext: Yes, so it was up 35% in the quarter, and we expect to be 30% for the full year, expecting the growth to moderate a bit going into -- quite a bit going into Q4. The conversation is very similar. Working through in each retailer, brand needs to go through an assessment of the business case and then piloting and then you get a partial adoption and full adoption. So no real change in the conversations. There's been in the last quarter since we talked about where the pipeline is, we've had 1 Tier 1 move from pilot into early adoption and then a couple of very small specialty retailers will be there from business case to pilot to pilot to adoption. So conversations pretty much the same, I'm seeing a little bit of migration to the pipeline as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Last 1 for me. Just around the share repurchases. I mean, obviously you don't make a decision based on what this will but the stock is down fairly dramatically today and I would think your internal model would be for share buyback here. How do you
componenttext: Got it. Last 1 for me. Just around the share repurchases. I mean, obviously you don't make a decision based on what this will but the stock is down fairly dramatically today and I would think your internal model would be for share buyback here. How do you think about share buyback into the end of the year?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as you talk about we don't really comment on timing and pace of share buyback. But we've been really consistent in how we look at this, but we look we do have an intrinsic value model. And as we see the gap, if we take out widening more aggressive in b
componenttext: So as you talk about we don't really comment on timing and pace of share buyback. But we've been really consistent in how we look at this, but we look we do have an intrinsic value model. And as we see the gap, if we take out widening more aggressive in buying back stock, and again as we see the gap less of a gap, then we don't buy that the start of that point. So we are a bit opportunistic in how we look at our share buyback program as well.

componenttextpreview: So we don't comment but you can probably infer from our past behavior that we will behave in such an environment.
componenttext: So we don't comment but you can probably infer from our past behavior that we will behave in such an environment.

componenttext: Yes. Really the biggest piece of the gap that you are talking about is from the beat we had with PSM this quarter. So even though the restructuring we gave guidance slightly is just more than $75 million. It could be a couple million dollars but we just want to give a bit of flavor on that but it's really the operational beat we have this quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My last 1 and then I'll turn over and try to come back. Back to RBIS, and we've asked similar questions, I guess, in the past around the business and your need to restructure. Recognizing it a challenging business and it's competitive, at the same t
componenttext: Okay. My last 1 and then I'll turn over and try to come back. Back to RBIS, and we've asked similar questions, I guess, in the past around the business and your need to restructure. Recognizing it a challenging business and it's competitive, at the same time, you're continuing to restructure and you're trying to stay ahead of kind of the base of competition and the other challenges in that market. At this juncture, given what you know, what 2 or 3 things make you confident that you can continue to retool that business, stay ahead of competition and ultimately hit your margin targets for RBIS by 2018?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think, overall, what makes us confident around that is the adjustments that we made -- started making last year, that we talk through at the beginning of what we said would be a multiyear transportation. We made quite a few adjustments, and a lo
componenttext: Yes. So I think, overall, what makes us confident around that is the adjustments that we made -- started making last year, that we talk through at the beginning of what we said would be a multiyear transportation. We made quite a few adjustments, and a lot of that was around moving more decision-making into that regions and closer to the customer, having a more segment approach depending different customers if ever full athletic performance athletic brand relative to a discounted retailer, they have different needs so we of adopt a more segmented approach. And as part of that, in some of the segments, that meant adjusting our cost structure to 1, expand margin led to come also to get more price competitive. Remember that the variable margin in this business even in what we call the less differentiated are relatively high. And so being able to drive consistent growth is a key requirement within this business as well. So -- what's what are the signs of success? It's based on welfare getting volume, of sure that we had for a couple of years going into mid last year. And we're seeing volume gains even though the market is down. And we basically proven the model ourselves internally so now it's a matter of pushing forward to accelerate. And as far as just to get to the margin target that we've laid out for 2018, if you recall, when we lay those out, we identified there is a lot amortization expense going away late in the cycle. So we've got to have basically the full point of expansion just from that. That's not new. We talk about it when we first laid out the targets. So that gives you a full point and then from there, primarily expect to be this year, you need less than a point of margin expansion over the 2 years to get to the low end and less than 2 points to get to the high end.

componenttext: Yes. So just specifically with that investment, it's coming online essentially for the year '18, 2018 is when it will be up and running so that's our expectation. And if you look at the investment that we're making, we're consistent we talked about pretty robust growth within Europe both Western Europe and also the combination of Western Europe and Eastern Europe. So this is business that actually haven't added a new for labels for quite a number of years. And so this is to fund the growth that we're seeing within that business right now, and we expect we'll continue to be investing in that region because it quite a bit of opportunity for continued growth there. As far as the CapEx timing, Anne, you want to comment?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So generally the bulk of the CapEx timing will take place in 2017. And the spending that we have this year was within the guidance that we gave at the beginning of the year of roughly $200 million for CapEx. And again, when we laid out our 2018 target, we
componenttext: So generally the bulk of the CapEx timing will take place in 2017. And the spending that we have this year was within the guidance that we gave at the beginning of the year of roughly $200 million for CapEx. And again, when we laid out our 2018 target, we said that on average, we would spend about $200 million in CapEx over the years. We were a little behind in the first couple of years of the guidance range, so I would expect us to still average around $200 million. It's just going to be a little more back weighted for the company.

componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And maybe just one last 1, it's kind of a follow-up to George's question on RBIS. componenttext: Yes, I think it's just basically continued execution of what we have been doing really taking the next step and accelerating what we have been doing. This is about winning in the market place and I'll tell you from what we're seeing and what we're hearing from customers, the change that we made are resonating. That gives us confidence. We're seeing the numbers behind that, volume gains in a period of declining market conditions. So that gives us confidence. And we just see opportunities around this business more efficiently as well. So there's quite a few leverage within the business of that size and don't want to go to each of the individual details but we feel not pleased with where the performance is but confident with the prospects of this business and what we're going to deliver.

componenttext: So there's a couple of components to it. Yes, this is a first quarter that we got Mactac in our balance sheet because that will distort some of the ratios a little bit. But in general, a couple of quarters, we talked about the fact that we were making some investments certain select areas in inventory primarily in RFID with RBIS. And so while we have continued to make progress and we have seen that inventory reduction come down as we played of the year, we still have an investment in that to carry through the end of this year and into next year.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I may ask one last 1. Your ratio price, selling price cost was negative as raw material costs seem to be rising. Are you expecting that ratio to worsen in the few quarters until you manage to get price up in line with the material cost?
componenttext: Okay. If I may ask one last 1. Your ratio price, selling price cost was negative as raw material costs seem to be rising. Are you expecting that ratio to worsen in the few quarters until you manage to get price up in line with the material cost?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So raw material costs, the environment we're seeing is relatively stable. You see some commodities like oil have been an upswing. But as far as what we're expecting, they've been relatively stable. And as far as the net impact of price and raw material co
componenttext: So raw material costs, the environment we're seeing is relatively stable. You see some commodities like oil have been an upswing. But as far as what we're expecting, they've been relatively stable. And as far as the net impact of price and raw material cost and talk about what the headwind was in the quarter. And over the long run, we've been pretty consistent in saying that some of the modest gains we've had in each quarter over the past couple of years basically over the long run, those eventually adjust for themselves, if you will, or correct. So we -- what we're seeing on the pricing, net pricing front is what we expected. The outperformance in PSM was largely around continued productivity. And our objective here is to consistently grow this business leveraging our innovation capabilities, which includes finding ways to reduce the material content of our products so that we can be competitive in the marketplace and grow the market as well driving returns and margins in this business.

componenttextpreview: I guess I'd like to go raw materials. I understand that your raw material costs were pretty benign, but propylene costs are up GBP 0.10 since April. And so that's going to move up acrylic prices in the fourth and in the first quarter. So is your attitude
componenttext: I guess I'd like to go raw materials. I understand that your raw material costs were pretty benign, but propylene costs are up GBP 0.10 since April. And so that's going to move up acrylic prices in the fourth and in the first quarter. So is your attitude that you're going to wait and see as the raw material costs move up as they do move up before you take pricing action? Or are you going to try to be more aggressive? What's your stance as some of the petrochemicals move up?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we saw a little bit modest inflation we talked last quarter but we'll see relatively individual components, Jeff, move in different directions but on balance it's where we're seeing things fairly muted if you will. So that's what we were referring
componenttext: Yes, so we saw a little bit modest inflation we talked last quarter but we'll see relatively individual components, Jeff, move in different directions but on balance it's where we're seeing things fairly muted if you will. So that's what we were referring to not an individual components. You're absolutely right in what you're seeing is what we're seeing for that component. But what we do is when there is inflation, and so if you are the start seeing inflation, we go through and we will announce pricing increases on which products or which regions is affecting. And good example of that is last year, we're still in a relatively deflationary environment. We raise prices, within some categories within Europe. So we went out and announce it and pushed it through. So we really got to think through about what the commodities were seeing is to bring U.S. dollars or if you are in euros, and so we basically make adjustments and we put price increases to where we see inflation.

They make UV LED curable inks and as part of our traffic jet solution within that business. And then on -- that was an investment was earlier in October, so it's not in the results right now. That's a minority investment. There was an GBP 18 million funding round that PragmatIC went through. We were less than half of that, I would say.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Why is your PSM growing faster than the U.S? Or are there particular markets in Europe that are healthier or more robust than are there particular PSM markets in the U.S. that are a little lackluster?
componenttext: Why is your PSM growing faster than the U.S? Or are there particular markets in Europe that are healthier or more robust than are there particular PSM markets in the U.S. that are a little lackluster?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Europe, broadly speaking, gets the benefit of Eastern Europe emerging markets. And that's the Eastern Europe this quarter is what's really was a key driver for them. But actually pretty consistently for the past years, even Western Europe we have talked a
componenttext: Europe, broadly speaking, gets the benefit of Eastern Europe emerging markets. And that's the Eastern Europe this quarter is what's really was a key driver for them. But actually pretty consistently for the past years, even Western Europe we have talked about was being higher than the U.S. And there's a number of factors behind that. We can't point to anyone. One of them is regulatory requirements, larger Label size and so forth. So there is not one thing I can point to that is 1 example. But to be honest, it's the differential between the U.S. and Western Europe has pretty much consistent we been a little bit bigger than we would have been expected. And talk about the market level not just --

componenttextpreview: And in the weakness in the U.S., was it confined to a particular market? Or it's too hard to tell?

componenttext: Not a particular market, no. It's relatively broad-based.
