componenttext: I want to come back to RFID and RBIS a little bit. So recognizing you're not giving guidance here for 2017, do you think, Mitch, over the next couple of years, let's frame it that way, that the outlook for adoption is as good as what we've seen, say, over the coming 12 months? I recognize it's retailer by retailer, et cetera, and it can come in and fairly large chunks. But if you had to frame it, is it as good, better, somewhat worse? How would have us consider it over the next couple of years?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say, it's as good and getting better. So basically, a year or so ago, we were talking about getting to an infection point starting to see some customers adopt. We've seen that. But it's really hard to call when that will happen to the point you raise.
componenttext: I'd say, it's as good and getting better. So basically, a year or so ago, we were talking about getting to an infection point starting to see some customers adopt. We've seen that. But it's really hard to call when that will happen to the point you raise. I mean, next year we expect this business to be double-digit growth. It could be just over 10% or it could be 30%. So timing specifically is hard to tell but over the long run, we definitely -- we talk about this business being a 20% growth business and that's what we continue to expect.

componenttext: Mitch, are the returns getting better to the retail adoption that's why the group has been so strong? Or are there other reasons why you'd see adoption? I would imagine have to be the former but again just want to get your thoughts on that.

componenttext: I think it's just more retailer by retailer and brand by brand them going through the process. componenttextpreview: Okay. Back to the margin question from earlier and again, we've talked about that before, yes, I was aware we have the drop off in D&A, they roll off from PACs, so if I look at the low end of your range, I guess, I will drill down and say what makes you c
componenttext: Okay. Back to the margin question from earlier and again, we've talked about that before, yes, I was aware we have the drop off in D&A, they roll off from PACs, so if I look at the low end of your range, I guess, I will drill down and say what makes you comfortable about getting that incremental 100 basis points or so? When I look at 2016, obviously, a lot of restructuring benefit to your credit but yet, the margins are at least in this quarter, kind of flat versus the year ago. So is it just for the restructuring that drives the majority of that 100 basis points? Is it more in your view the RFID element, which you are quite obviously positive on? What gives you confidence in a phase capturing that last 100 basis points above and beyond the D&A component?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really a balance between having the growth strategy as well as driving further productivity. And if you look at the business, we've consistently delivered over 0.5 point a year of margin expansion regardless of what's going on in the top line. And if
componenttext: It's really a balance between having the growth strategy as well as driving further productivity. And if you look at the business, we've consistently delivered over 0.5 point a year of margin expansion regardless of what's going on in the top line. And if you look over the last few years, we've grown this business 2.5%. So our objective here is ensure we can get those margin targets even in a lower growth scenario than the 4% to 5% we targeted. We will get there even in this lower growth environment and ensuring there's upside as we develop and push through our growth strategy so that when we started giving up 4% to 5% growth, which is still our goal, you will then have further uplift from there.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the third quarter ended October 1, 2016. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 10:00 a.m. Pacific time today through midn
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to Avery Dennison's Earnings Conference Call for the third quarter ended October 1, 2016. This call is being recorded and will be available for replay from 10:00 a.m. Pacific time today through midnight Pacific time October 29. To access the replay, please dial (800) 633-8284 or (402) 977-9140 for international callers. The conference ID number is 21782908. [Operator Instructions] 
I'd now like to turn the call over to Cindy Guenther, Avery Dennison's Vice President of Finance and Investor Relations. Please go ahead, ma'am.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Dmitra. Today, we'll discuss our preliminary unaudited third quarter results. The non-GAAP financial measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP on Schedules A-4 to A-8 of the financial statements accompanying today's e
componenttext:
Thank you, Dmitra. Today, we'll discuss our preliminary unaudited third quarter results. The non-GAAP financial measures that we use are defined, qualified and reconciled with GAAP on Schedules A-4 to A-8 of the financial statements accompanying today's earnings release. We remind you that we'll make certain predictive statements that reflect our current views and estimates about our future performance and financial results. These forward-looking statements are made subject to the safe harbor statement included in today's earnings release.
On the call today are Mitch Butier, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Anne Bramman, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
I'll now turn the call over to Mitch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Cindy, and good day, everyone. We had another quarter of strong earnings growth with EPS above our expectations.We are improving our competitiveness with continued strong profitability across the PSM portfolio and making progress with our busine
componenttext:
Thanks, Cindy, and good day, everyone. We had another quarter of strong earnings growth with EPS above our expectations.
We are improving our competitiveness with continued strong profitability across the PSM portfolio and making progress with our business model transformation in RBIS.
As expected, organic sales growth in Pressure-sensitive Materials moderated in the third quarter to 3%, reflecting the program loss in the personal care segment of Performance Tapes that we've discussed previously. Excluding this program loss, sales grew 4.5% organically.
Once again, emerging markets were the key growth driver for PSM, more than offsetting softness in the North American market. From a product perspective, the base label materials business remained healthy with solid top line growth overall and margins expanding across most categories. Graphics and specialty label materials were up high single-digits for the quarter on a global basis. I'm pleased with our progress in shifting PSM's portfolio mix towards these higher value categories. We expect continued benefit over the long term from our focus and investment in these areas. Speaking of which, the integration of our acquisition of the Mactac graphics and tapes business, which we completed in August is going smoothly. We also completed a very small acquisition of Ink Mill during the quarter, which expands our capabilities in the high-value reflectives business. And earlier this month, we made an equity investment in the U.K.-based startup called PragmatIC, leveraging our strength in RFID to enable long-term growth of intelligent labels in new segments. 
All 3 of these recent deals exemplify the range of opportunities we have identified and continue to pursue within our M&A pipeline, with a focus on high-value product lines and supporting technologies.
Our commitment to investing here in terms of both M&A and higher capital spending is reinforced by the excellent progress we've made with the high-value segments through which we have delivered consistent organic growth, improved mix and strong profitability and returns.
Shifting now to Retail Branding and Information Solutions. Sales were up a little over 2% organically driven by Radio Frequency Identification. RFID sales were up over 35% in Q3 and are expected to exceed 30% for the full year. While the pace of growth was slow in the fourth quarter, reflecting the difficult comparison the prior year that we've discussed, we expect the RFID will continue to be a key growth driver for us.
We are continuing to invest in this high-value product line, expanding capacity and improving our manufacturing processes as well as participating in promising new ventures like PragmatIC.
Outside of RFID, top line growth was short of our target for the quarter amidst a difficult retail apparel market in the U.S. particularly among the department stores.
That said, we saw solid volume gains across the base business, representing clear signs of success for our multiyear transformation strategy as we become faster, simpler and more competitive while driving margin expansion.
Our strategy is the right one. Moving decision-making closer to our markets, reducing complexity as well as our cost structure and qualifying lower-cost, locally sourced materials to support more competitive pricing.
Our improvements in service, flexibility and speed are resonating with customers. In light of the soft top line though, these actions have not been enough to deliver the margin expansion we had targeted for the year. Now we will accelerate our efforts through 2017 to further improve our competitiveness and achieve our 2018 margin expansion target.
So coming back to the total company view. Overall, we've made good progress against our strategic and financial objectives as evidenced by another solid quarter and a $0.10 increase to expected EPS for the year.
We remain highly confident in our ability to consistently deliver exceptional value over the long run based on the execution of our key strategies. First and foremost, we will drive outsized growth in high-value segments. We will continue to invest disproportionately here both organically and through bolt-on acquisitions. Over time, this will improve our portfolio mix and bolster our leadership in these key segments.
Second, we are relentless in our pursuit of productivity improvement to enhance our competitiveness across all product categories and, of course, to drive margin expansion.
And third, we are maintaining our high degree of capital efficiency while increasing investments to support profitable growth and, of course, we will continue our disciplined approach to returning cash to shareholders.
Now I will turn the call over to Anne.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mitch. Providing a little more color on the quarter. In Q3, we delivered a 16% increase in adjusted earnings per share on 3% organic sales growth. Currency translation reduced reported sales by 1.7% in the third quarter, which was offset by the li
componenttext:
Thanks, Mitch. Providing a little more color on the quarter. In Q3, we delivered a 16% increase in adjusted earnings per share on 3% organic sales growth. Currency translation reduced reported sales by 1.7% in the third quarter, which was offset by the lift from the Mactac acquisition.
Adjusted operating margin in the third quarter improved 40 basis points to 9.8% as the benefit of productivity initiatives and higher volume more than offset higher employee-related expenses and the net impact of price and raw material input cost. We realized about $21 million of incremental savings from restructuring charges net of transition costs. The adjusted tax rate for the quarter was 31%, reflecting a reduction to our estimate for the full year effective tax rate from 34% at the end of Q2 to 33% due to stronger income growth and lower tax jurisdictions.
Year-to-date, free cash flow was $248 million, an increase of $57 million compared to last year. During the first 9 months of the year, we repurchased approximately 2.7 million shares and paid $106 million in dividends. Net of dilution, we reduced our share count by approximately 1 million shares for a net cost of $118 million, bringing the total amount of cash returned to shareholders so far this year to roughly $224 million. Our balance sheet remained strong, and we have ample capacity to continue funding acquisitions as well as returning cash to shareholders in a disciplined manner.
We funded the acquisition of Mactac Europe through euro-denominated commercial paper. We will explore a euro-denominated debt offering in the first half of next year to refinance notes that will be maturing later in 2017 as well as the Mactac acquisition. Our objective will be to take advantage of the low interest rates in Europe and the opportunity to hedge currency exposure on our balance sheet. 
Now looking at the segments. Pressure-sensitive Materials sales were up approximately 3% on an organic basis. Emerging markets continue to be strong contributors to growth through the segment, representing virtually all of the top line growth in the third quarter. Excluding the impact of the program loss in Performance Tapes, emerging market sales were up over 10% organically comparable to the pace we saw in the second quarter. This strength was fairly widespread across the countries that comprise emerging markets. Of particular note, the underlying growth trend in China picked up modestly compared to the second quarter. You may recall that sales in China were roughly flat in Q2 on an organic basis. Adjusting for holiday timing and the tapes loss, we estimate the underlying organic sales growth for China was back to the low single digit rate we saw in the first quarter of this year and for 2015 as a whole. 
Turning to the mature markets. In North America, sales declined at a low single-digit rate on an organic basis. This reflects a soft market and the pass-through of savings from deflation, while Western Europe was up low single-digits. Demand in Western Europe has been consistently growing at solid low- to mid-single digit rates and on occasion even higher. Factoring in Eastern Europe, the overall European market has been a strong source of growth for us and we expect that strength to continue.
We are investing to keep pace with the growth in this region, recently announcing a $65 million investment over the next 1.5 years to expand both the capabilities and capacity of our flagship operation in Luxembourg. From a product line perspective, Label and Packaging Materials sales were up mid-single digits organically, while sales for the combined Graphics and Performance Tapes product lines were down low single-digits reflecting the expected program loss for tapes.
Excluding the program loss, combined sales for Graphics and Performance Tapes were up mid-single digits on an organic basis.
Pressure-sensitive Materials adjusted operating margin of 12.6% was up 50 basis points over last year as the benefits from productivity and higher volume more than offset the net impact of price and raw material input cost as well as unfavorable mix. 
Shifting now to Retail Branding and Information Solutions. RBIS sales grew 2% on an organic basis driven by growth of RFID. Sales outside of RFID continue to be soft down low single digits, reflecting modest growth in volume, which was more than offset by the impact of strategic pricing actions that we began taking late last year.
As you know, we began adjusting our prices in late 2015 to become more competitive, so the sales growth comparisons for the base business become modestly easier in the fourth quarter. As Mitch said, we do believe that the transformation of our business model becoming more cost and price competitive while providing better and faster service is driving volume growth albeit in a challenging retail apparel environment that makes it tough to see the impact of these wins in our financial results.
From a regional perspective, we saw strong mid-single-digit unit point growth for core Label products among European retailers and brand owners due in part to continued progress in expanding our share among the fast fashion players.
Unit volumes for core products were flat in the U.S, an improvement over the mid-single-digit decline we saw last quarter. This market is especially challenged as demonstrated by macro indicators. In particular, apparel imports into the U.S. were down on average by about 3% for the most recent 3 months reported. And since the fourth quarter of last year, the inventory to sales ratio for U.S. apparel has been at prerecession level. Adjusted operating margin for the segment improved by 20 basis points as the net savings from the business model transformation was largely offset by higher employee-related costs. We have not changed our long-term margin expansion objectives for this business and expect to achieve the goal we set for 2018.
As expected, sales for Vancive Medical Technologies were down 20% on an organic basis in the quarter, reflecting the combined effect of share losses and customer inventory reductions. We were able to partially offset the impact of the sales loss through cost-reduction actions. Going forward, the steps we began taking mid last year should enable consistent growth and significant margin expansion over the long term. 
Now turning to our outlook for the rest of the year. We have raised the midpoint of the range of our guidance for full year adjusted earnings per share by $0.10 to $3.95 to $4. This reflects the better-than-expected operating results that we delivered in the third quarter, including the lower expected tax rate.
We outlined some of the key contributing factors to our EPS guidance on Slide 8 of our supplemental presentation material.
Highlighting the changes from our previous expectations, we have reduced the high end of our organic growth outlook and now expect full year sales to grow between 3% and 3.5% on an organic basis.
We now expect more than $75 million from restructuring savings net of transition cost for the year. And as discussed previously, we now expect an effective tax rate of approximately 33%.
So just wrapping up. We're very pleased with the strategic and financial progress made against our 2018 goals this past quarter. We're confident we can continue to deliver exceptional value over the long term through superior execution of our strategies, including the disciplined allocation of capital. Now we'll open the call up for your questions.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Ghansham Panjabi with Robert W. Baird and Company.

componenttext: First off, did you see any measurable change in core sales growth for PSM in any particular month during 3Q? There been some companies and different industries that have commented on the slowdown in Europe in the quarter, wondering if you saw any deviation in the quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so we do normally see some variation month-to-month. We did see a little bit of a slide during Q3 over in Europe. Having said that, we're seeing a little bit of an uptick in early October as well within Europe as well as North America. So I don't re
componenttext: Well, so we do normally see some variation month-to-month. We did see a little bit of a slide during Q3 over in Europe. Having said that, we're seeing a little bit of an uptick in early October as well within Europe as well as North America. So I don't read too much into individual month trends too closely because it's not unusual for us to see 4 weeks of strong performance followed by a softening or vice versa.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then what exactly, Mitch, is do you think driving the weakness in North American PSM? Is that just sort of inventory reductions? What do you think is going on by channel there?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then what exactly, Mitch, is do you think driving the weakness in North American PSM? Is that just sort of inventory reductions? What do you think is going on by channel there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to say. We think there's been a softening in the end consumption of the market in Q3, but we don't have that data right now. But we also did cede some share earlier in the year within that business as we're driving more discipline on the lower v
componenttext: It's hard to say. We think there's been a softening in the end consumption of the market in Q3, but we don't have that data right now. But we also did cede some share earlier in the year within that business as we're driving more discipline on the lower value less differentiated segments. But in the quarter, we think this -- it basically softened a bit. We don't have clear reasons why. At Labelexpo, the sentiment from North American converters was overall I'd say, most of them were very confident in their individual businesses, cautious about the market overall. But also talked about how they themselves, have less visibility to their own order volumes than they traditionally have had as well. So it's hard to give you a read on exactly what's going on in the North American business. Clearly, some of the decline was from Graphics, if you will, within that region specifically. But it's hard to give you a clear read here. As I said, first few weeks of October, we're starting to see an uptick.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just one final one for me. You also called out higher raw material cost for 3Q, can you first of all expand on that? And then also, how were you kind of positioning the company for what could be an increase in inflation as we head into 2017 comi
componenttext: Okay, and just one final one for me. You also called out higher raw material cost for 3Q, can you first of all expand on that? And then also, how were you kind of positioning the company for what could be an increase in inflation as we head into 2017 coming off a period of a few quarters anyway of deflation?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ghansham, so we -- what we really said was that we saw the -- an impact to our margins of price net of raw material input cost. And so relatively speaking, we don't give specific color on pricing inflation, but as we've been pretty consistent in sayi
componenttext: Yes. Ghansham, so we -- what we really said was that we saw the -- an impact to our margins of price net of raw material input cost. And so relatively speaking, we don't give specific color on pricing inflation, but as we've been pretty consistent in saying that we broadly have given some price reduction statements where we have relatively higher variable margins and we may have seen some through deflation. And we basically then passing it along to customers in some targeted areas. And in our -- in my script, I specifically called out that we've seen that, that impact in North America.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Louis Gaffner with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Louis Gaffner with Barclays Capital.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, just wanted to go back to RBIS for a second. You mentioned the North American apparel retailers and some of the import data, are there any categories in particular within that channel that you're seeing any weakness in? And then what about European
componenttext: Mitch, just wanted to go back to RBIS for a second. You mentioned the North American apparel retailers and some of the import data, are there any categories in particular within that channel that you're seeing any weakness in? And then what about European retailers? If you could just give some color there as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the categories within the U.S. department stores in particular, are seeing softness, and we're seeing that as well with our key customers in that space. But generally, I think it's relatively broad-based in the data that Anne shared is across the
componenttext: Yes, so the categories within the U.S. department stores in particular, are seeing softness, and we're seeing that as well with our key customers in that space. But generally, I think it's relatively broad-based in the data that Anne shared is across the entire retail apparel sector, if you will. So inventory levels, return to back this year to their prerecession high. If you recall for a few years after recession, they were quite a bit lower. Those have bulked up. A good portion of that relates to the fact that it was a very warm winter last year and just there was not as much as sell-through as we've been holding on in the inventory. So I know the goal is for retailers to flush some of their inventory out of the system through this holiday season. And then for Europe, it depends. Overall, we also softness in the U.K. Clearly, the U.K. retailers with Brexit going on, I think, are struggling a bit. And so that's one place we see softness. But in Germany, pretty solid. Other markets, we're seeing relatively solid performance at the end retail level.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any you said RFID up 30% in the quarter. With some of the weakness in apparel, are there any change in the conversation with your customers around adoption rates on RFID?
componenttext: Okay. And any you said RFID up 30% in the quarter. With some of the weakness in apparel, are there any change in the conversation with your customers around adoption rates on RFID?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it was up 35% in the quarter, and we expect to be 30% for the full year, expecting the growth to moderate a bit going into -- quite a bit going into Q4. The conversations very similar. Working through in each retailer or brand need to go through a
componenttext: Yes, so it was up 35% in the quarter, and we expect to be 30% for the full year, expecting the growth to moderate a bit going into -- quite a bit going into Q4. The conversations very similar. Working through in each retailer or brand need to go through an assessment of the business case and then piloting and then you get a partial adoption and full adoption. So no real change in the conversations. There's been in the last quarter since we talked about where the pipeline is, we've had one Tier 1 move from pilot into early adoption and then a couple of very small specialty retailers move either from business case to pilot or pilot to adoption. So conversations pretty much the same, seeing a little bit of migration to the pipeline as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last one for me just around the share repurchases. I mean, obviously you don't make a decision based on 1 day's move but the stock is down fairly dramatically today, and I would think your internal model would be screening well for share buyback her
componenttext: Okay. Last one for me just around the share repurchases. I mean, obviously you don't make a decision based on 1 day's move but the stock is down fairly dramatically today, and I would think your internal model would be screening well for share buyback here. How do you think about share buyback into the end of the year?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as you talk about, we don't really comment on timing and pace of share buyback, but -- and we've been really consistent in how we look at this. But we look -- we do have an intrinsic value model. And as we see the gap -- if we see a gap widening, we wi
componenttext: So as you talk about, we don't really comment on timing and pace of share buyback, but -- and we've been really consistent in how we look at this. But we look -- we do have an intrinsic value model. And as we see the gap -- if we see a gap widening, we will be much more aggressive in buying back stock. And again as we see the gap less of a gap, then we don't buy back as much stock at that point. So we are a bit opportunistic in how we look at our share buyback programs as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Scott, we don't comment, but you can probably infer from our past behavior how we would behave in such an environment.
componenttext: Yes. So Scott, we don't comment, but you can probably infer from our past behavior how we would behave in such an environment.

componenttext: Thanks, George.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess the first question I had, recognizing the answer is probably both when we look at the slight reduction in the core growth rate you're expecting, Mitch, is it more centered in RBIS, given the weakness in retail? Or is it in the somewhat difficult t
componenttext: I guess the first question I had, recognizing the answer is probably both when we look at the slight reduction in the core growth rate you're expecting, Mitch, is it more centered in RBIS, given the weakness in retail? Or is it in the somewhat difficult to pin down but nonetheless apparent reduction in consumption in Pressure-sensitive Materials in, I think, the U.S. is what you said? Which one of those is a bigger driver of this modest trend there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So George, are you asking about Q3 or Q4 because you can kind of triangulate what that actually takes...
componenttext: So George, are you asking about Q3 or Q4 because you can kind of triangulate what that actually takes...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was meaning it really more for the full year outlook, but answer it however you feel is most illustrative.
componenttext: I was meaning it really more for the full year outlook, but answer it however you feel is most illustrative.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So overall, I mean, RBIS you can see where the growth rate is, a little over 2%. And so we expect roughly a continuation of that. Obviously, it can be a little lower, a little higher, depending on how things pan out and a couple of key contributing f
componenttext: Yes. So overall, I mean, RBIS you can see where the growth rate is, a little over 2%. And so we expect roughly a continuation of that. Obviously, it can be a little lower, a little higher, depending on how things pan out and a couple of key contributing factors. We have harder RFID comps, if you will. We have a couple of things that ease up on the comps front in that business. So that's what we're thinking within RBIS, the continuation. And within pressure sensitive, the Q3, the revenue was lower than we're thinking that business would come in at, and it was specifically around North America. And so it's really a question about is it early trends we see in October continue a positive trend that we're seeing? Or does it revert back to a lower level?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is October more or less in line with what you would have expected otherwise? And obviously, it's up -- is it up where you would have liked it to have been?
componenttext: Okay. Is October more or less in line with what you would have expected otherwise? And obviously, it's up -- is it up where you would have liked it to have been?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's consistent with our guidance range that we've provided. One thing is very hard to read Asia, North Asia in particular because of the calendar shift of the Golden Week, so basically their harvest festival, if you will. So that distorted things. So any
componenttext: It's consistent with our guidance range that we've provided. One thing is very hard to read Asia, North Asia in particular because of the calendar shift of the Golden Week, so basically their harvest festival, if you will. So that distorted things. So anything for RBIS because so much is sourced out of North Asia as well as North Asia for materials group, is not a good read. North America rebounded like we said, and Europe has rebounded a little bit from the softening in Q3 as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Now one of the question I had, if I look at the guidance increase, and it was roughly $0.10. The tax effect in the third quarter is probably a couple of pennies. The FX negative is about a couple of pennies more favorable. Is there a way to split th
componenttext: Okay. Now one of the question I had, if I look at the guidance increase, and it was roughly $0.10. The tax effect in the third quarter is probably a couple of pennies. The FX negative is about a couple of pennies more favorable. Is there a way to split the remaining difference between restructuring what you said is in excess of $75 million, but you don't necessarily say how much, and any other factors that are benefiting you?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really the biggest piece of the gap that you are talking about, it's from the beat that we had with PSM this quarter. So even though the restructuring we gave guidance, it's a slightly -- it's just slightly more than $75 million. We -- it could be a
componenttext: It's really the biggest piece of the gap that you are talking about, it's from the beat that we had with PSM this quarter. So even though the restructuring we gave guidance, it's a slightly -- it's just slightly more than $75 million. We -- it could be a couple million or we just want to give a bit of flavor on that, but it's really the operational beat we have this quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My last one and then I'll turn over and try to come back. Back to RBIS, and we've asked similar questions, I guess, in the past around the business and your need to restructure. Recognizing it a challenging business and it's competitive, at the same
componenttext: Okay. My last one and then I'll turn over and try to come back. Back to RBIS, and we've asked similar questions, I guess, in the past around the business and your need to restructure. Recognizing it a challenging business and it's competitive, at the same time, you're continuing to restructure and you're trying to stay ahead of kind of the pace of competition and the other challenges in that market. At this juncture, given what you know, what 2 or 3 things make you confident that you can continue to retool that business, stay ahead of competition and ultimately hit your margin targets for RBIS by 2018?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think, overall, what makes us confident around that is the adjustments that we made -- started making last year, that we talk through and it was the beginning of what we said would be a multiyear transformation. We made quite a few adjustments,
componenttext: Yes. So I think, overall, what makes us confident around that is the adjustments that we made -- started making last year, that we talk through and it was the beginning of what we said would be a multiyear transformation. We made quite a few adjustments, and a lot of that was around moving more decision-making into the regions and closer to the customer, having a more segmented approach depending -- different customers if it's a performance athletic, high-end performance athletic brand relative to a discounted retailer, they have different needs so we've adopted a more segmented approach. And as part of that, in some of the -- in some segments, that meant adjusting our cost structure to: one, expand margin; but two, also to get more price competitive. Remember that the variable margin in this business even in what we call the less differentiated are relatively high. And so being able to drive consistent growth is a key requirement within this business as well. So -- what's -- what are the signs of success? It's basically we're getting volume gains. We've stopped the share slide that we had for a couple of years going into mid last year. And we're seeing volume gains even though the market is down. And we've basically proven the model ourselves internally so now it's a matter of pushing forward to accelerate. And as far as just to get to the margin target that we've laid out for 2018, if you recall, when we laid those out, we identified, there's a lot amortization expense going away late in the cycle. So we got to have basically the full point of expansion just from that. That's not new. We talked about it when we first laid out the targets. So that gives you a full point. And then from there, from where we expect to be this year, you need less than a point of margin expansion over 2 years to get to the low end and less than 2 points to get to the high end.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Forgive me, I joined in a bit late so forgive me if I'm repeating anything, but it sounds like you reduced -- you slightly reduced your organic sales growth guidance on account of some weakness in North America and PSM. Am I on the mark so far?
componenttext: Forgive me, I joined in a bit late so forgive me if I'm repeating anything, but it sounds like you reduced -- you slightly reduced your organic sales growth guidance on account of some weakness in North America and PSM. Am I on the mark so far?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we -- when we look at our guidance, yes, we came in a little bit softer on the -- on North America for PSM. But I think if you look at the full year guidance, the reality is we're going to be around the midpoint. If you look at the 2 ranges, you'd
componenttext: Yes. So we -- when we look at our guidance, yes, we came in a little bit softer on the -- on North America for PSM. But I think if you look at the full year guidance, the reality is we're going to be around the midpoint. If you look at the 2 ranges, you'd have to assume a pretty significant change in the run rate in Q4 for the businesses. And on the downside piece to it, you'd have to assume a reversal in trend for all the businesses as well. So the likelihood is we're going to be around the midpoint.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: But -- and you raised your guidance partly on tax, and I think you said partly on better PSM? Is that right?
componenttext: But -- and you raised your guidance partly on tax, and I think you said partly on better PSM? Is that right?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. And I will quote, clarify on the tax, that's really a contributor from PSM as well. We saw very favorable geo mix of where the income was coming from, from the lower tax jurisdictions. So I really consider that kind of operational beat as well.
componenttext: Correct. And I will quote, clarify on the tax, that's really a contributor from PSM as well. We saw very favorable geo mix of where the income was coming from, from the lower tax jurisdictions. So I really consider that kind of operational beat as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you have -- so just -- so you have lower sales expectations for PSM broadly, but you have higher profit expectations for PSM for the year presumably on margins, right?
componenttext: So you have -- so just -- so you have lower sales expectations for PSM broadly, but you have higher profit expectations for PSM for the year presumably on margins, right?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's -- and why the margin upside, given the sales -- given the tails are a bit light?
componenttext: And that's -- and why the margin upside, given the sales -- given the tails are a bit light?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So again, a similar story than what we had in the last couple of quarters is productivity continues to be a very strong performer for this division. And in this quarter, we continued to deliver on the productivity front. So really the beat we had tha
componenttext: Yes. So again, a similar story than what we had in the last couple of quarters is productivity continues to be a very strong performer for this division. And in this quarter, we continued to deliver on the productivity front. So really the beat we had that we're showing for the full year guidance came from this quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just in terms of your implied 4Q guidance, it's the midpoint around $0.95 compared to last year's $0.85. Last year, you had a pretty low tax rates. So can you just help us understand what the primary drivers of that year-over-year growth are?
componenttext: Okay. And just in terms of your implied 4Q guidance, it's the midpoint around $0.95 compared to last year's $0.85. Last year, you had a pretty low tax rates. So can you just help us understand what the primary drivers of that year-over-year growth are?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So for our guidance, for the margin, we would assume the normal seasonal margin, sequential margin pieces from Q3 to Q4 for PSM. And we are -- and traditionally the RBIS business does have a higher margin sequentially from Q3 to Q4 that we also have baked
componenttext: So for our guidance, for the margin, we would assume the normal seasonal margin, sequential margin pieces from Q3 to Q4 for PSM. And we are -- and traditionally the RBIS business does have a higher margin sequentially from Q3 to Q4 that we also have baked in. So you look at our guidance range really the biggest component of it is where will the margins deliver for RBIS.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari with Citigroup Global Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari with Citigroup Global Markets.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the investment in Luxembourg, is it possible to say when the capacity becomes available or when it ramps? And then how much of that $65 million investment shows up in 2016 CapEx versus 2017? And kind of any early view on 2017 CapEx?
componenttext: With the investment in Luxembourg, is it possible to say when the capacity becomes available or when it ramps? And then how much of that $65 million investment shows up in 2016 CapEx versus 2017? And kind of any early view on 2017 CapEx?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just specifically with that investment, it's coming online essentially for the year '18. 2018 is when it will be up and running, so that's our expectation. And if you look at the investment that we're making, we've consistently talked about pretty
componenttext: Yes. So just specifically with that investment, it's coming online essentially for the year '18. 2018 is when it will be up and running, so that's our expectation. And if you look at the investment that we're making, we've consistently talked about pretty robust growth within Europe both Western Europe and also the combination of Western Europe and Eastern Europe. So this is a business that actually we haven't added a new coder in for labels for quite a number of years. And so this is to fund the growth that we're seeing within that business right now, and we expect we'll continue to be investing in that region because we see quite a bit of opportunity for continued growth there. As far as the CapEx timing, Anne, you want to comment?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So generally, the bulk of the CapEx timing will take place in 2017. And the spending that we have this year was within the guidance that we gave at the beginning of the year of roughly $200 million for CapEx. And again, when we laid out our 2018 targ
componenttext: Yes. So generally, the bulk of the CapEx timing will take place in 2017. And the spending that we have this year was within the guidance that we gave at the beginning of the year of roughly $200 million for CapEx. And again, when we laid out our 2018 target, we said that on average, we would spend about $200 million in CapEx over the years. We were a little behind in the first couple of years of that guidance range, so I would expect to see it's still average around the $200 million. It's just going to be a little more back weighted or raw for the company.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, that's very helpful. And then in RBIS, I think in the last quarter, you indicated you were impacted by store closures in athletic goods. And I'm wondering given what they've been reading in a very challenging retail environment, are store clos
componenttext: Okay. Okay, that's very helpful. And then in RBIS, I think in the last quarter, you indicated you were impacted by store closures in athletic goods. And I'm wondering given what they've been reading in a very challenging retail environment, are store closures -- are they still a headwind in 3Q? And does that may be a drag through the end of the year? Or any kind of color you can give there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's always some consolidation with store closures. And what you see is what we see. Specifically, what we commented on before was the fact that there was some bankruptcies of some athletic store -- athletic chains. So -- and that affected performance
componenttext: There's always some consolidation with store closures. And what you see is what we see. Specifically, what we commented on before was the fact that there was some bankruptcies of some athletic store -- athletic chains. So -- and that affected performance athletic. If you recall it had declined last quarter, which was exceptional because usually we see very consistent growth. So that category for us returned to growth in this past -- in Q3.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And maybe just one last one, and it's kind of a follow-up to George's question on RBIS. In your remarks, you referenced accelerating the RBIS margin improvement program. And I was wondering if you'd give a little color on the leverag
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And maybe just one last one, and it's kind of a follow-up to George's question on RBIS. In your remarks, you referenced accelerating the RBIS margin improvement program. And I was wondering if you'd give a little color on the leverage you can pull there from here on out. Do you need to get more aggressive on the price adjustments? Or are there additional cost that you can take out? Or would you get more aggressive on M&A? Or just how should we think about the levers you can pull to accelerate the RBIS margin improvement?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's just basically continued execution of what we've been doing but really taking the next step and accelerating what we have been doing. This is about winning in the marketplace. And I'll tell you from what we're seeing and what we're heari
componenttext: Yes, I think it's just basically continued execution of what we've been doing but really taking the next step and accelerating what we have been doing. This is about winning in the marketplace. And I'll tell you from what we're seeing and what we're hearing from customers, the change that we made are resonating. That gives us confidence. We're seeing the numbers behind that, volume gains in a period of declining market conditions. So that gives us confidence. And we just see opportunity to run this business more efficiently as well. So there's quite a few levers within a business of that size and don't want to go through each of the individual details. But we feel not pleased with where the performance is, but confident with the prospects of this business and what we're going to deliver.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rosemarie Morbelli with Gabelli & Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Rosemarie Morbelli with Gabelli & Company.

componenttext: I was wondering if you could give us a feel for the growth rate in the athletic chains, following the softness in the previous quarter. What is the normal rate that you are expecting? And are you there in the third quarter?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this can have a little bit of volatility to it, but it's consistently grown above the average for the overall segment and pretty relatively consistently mid-single digits to higher. So -- and that's where it was within Q3.
componenttext: So this can have a little bit of volatility to it, but it's consistently grown above the average for the overall segment and pretty relatively consistently mid-single digits to higher. So -- and that's where it was within Q3.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And could you give us some detail as to the inventory increase? I mean, versus last year, inventories up 10% versus revenues, up 2.7%. Is this Mactac? Or is something else going on?
componenttext: Okay. And could you give us some detail as to the inventory increase? I mean, versus last year, inventories up 10% versus revenues, up 2.7%. Is this Mactac? Or is something else going on?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Rosemarie, there's a couple of components to it. Yes, this is the first quarter that we got Mactac in our balance sheet because that will distort some of your ratios a little bit. But in general, a couple of quarters ago that we talked about the fact t
componenttext: So Rosemarie, there's a couple of components to it. Yes, this is the first quarter that we got Mactac in our balance sheet because that will distort some of your ratios a little bit. But in general, a couple of quarters ago that we talked about the fact that we were making some investments in certain select areas in inventory primarily in RFID with RBIS. And so while we have continued to make progress and we have seen that inventory reductions come down as we've played out the year, we still have an investment in that in order to carry us through the end of this year and to next year.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is making sure you have the proper inventory in anticipation of the changes you are making?
componenttext: So this is making sure you have the proper inventory in anticipation of the changes you are making?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's the pipeline of RFID customers that we've got to make sure that we're meeting their demand.
componenttext: It's the pipeline of RFID customers that we've got to make sure that we're meeting their demand.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I may ask one last one. Your ratio price -- selling price cost was negative as raw material costs seemed to be rising. Are you expecting that ratio to worsen in the few quarters until you manage to get price up in line with the material cost?
componenttext: Okay. If I may ask one last one. Your ratio price -- selling price cost was negative as raw material costs seemed to be rising. Are you expecting that ratio to worsen in the few quarters until you manage to get price up in line with the material cost?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So raw material cost, the environment we're seeing is relatively stable. You see some commodities like oil have been on an upswing. But as far as what we're experiencing, they've been relatively stable. And as far as the net impact of price and raw materi
componenttext: So raw material cost, the environment we're seeing is relatively stable. You see some commodities like oil have been on an upswing. But as far as what we're experiencing, they've been relatively stable. And as far as the net impact of price and raw material cost, we -- Anne talked about what the headwind was in the quarter. And over the long run, we've been pretty consistent in saying that some of the modest gains we've had in each quarter over the past couple of years basically over the long run, those eventually adjust for themselves, if you will, or correct. So we -- what we're seeing on the pricing -- net pricing front is what we expected. The outperformance in PSM was largely around continued productivity. And our objective here is to consistently grow this business leveraging our innovation capabilities, which includes finding ways to reduce the material content of our products so that we can be competitive in the marketplace and grow the market while driving returns and margins in this business.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one very quick one if I may. When are you -- when are we anniversary-ing the program loss in Performance Tapes?
componenttext: And one very quick one if I may. When are you -- when are we anniversary-ing the program loss in Performance Tapes?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we had a small piece of that in the first half of the year, but I would expect to see headwinds in the second half as the program loss we really start feeling that in Q3.
componenttext: So we had a small piece of that in the first half of the year, but I would expect to see headwinds in the second half as the program loss we really start feeling that in Q3.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's basically mid-next year is the rough rule you should see, Rosemarie.
componenttext: It's basically mid-next year is the rough rule you should see, Rosemarie.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next quarter comes from the line of Jeffrey John Zekauskas with JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: Our next quarter comes from the line of Jeffrey John Zekauskas with JPMorgan Securities.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess I'd like to go back to raw materials. I understand that your raw material costs were pretty benign, but propylene costs are up $0.10 a pound since April. And so that's going to move up acrylic prices in the fourth and in the first quarter. So i
componenttext: So I guess I'd like to go back to raw materials. I understand that your raw material costs were pretty benign, but propylene costs are up $0.10 a pound since April. And so that's going to move up acrylic prices in the fourth and in the first quarter. So is your attitude that you're going to wait and see as the raw material costs move up as they do move up before you take pricing action? Or are you going to try to be more aggressive? What's your stance as some of the petrochemical values move up?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we saw a little bit a modest inflation that we talked about last quarter, but we've seen relative instability. And individual components, Jeff, move in different directions, but on balances where we're seeing things fairly muted, if you will. So t
componenttext: Yes. So we saw a little bit a modest inflation that we talked about last quarter, but we've seen relative instability. And individual components, Jeff, move in different directions, but on balances where we're seeing things fairly muted, if you will. So that's what we were referring to, not any individual components. You're absolutely right in what you're seeing as what we're seeing for that component. But what we do is when there is inflation -- if so if we were to -- if we start seeing inflation, we go through and we will announce price increases on which products or which regions it's affecting. And a good example of that is last year, we were still in a relatively deflationary environment. We raise prices within film categories within Europe. So we went out and announced it and pushed it through. So you've really got to think through about what the commodities were seeing is different in U.S. dollars or if you are in euros, and so we basically make adjustments and we'll put price increases to where we see inflation.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. You made a couple of small acquisitions. What did you pay for them and what did you get? That is, what was the either the revenues or the EBITDA? And what were the costs of your 2 small acquisitions?
componenttext: Okay. You made a couple of small acquisitions. What did you pay for them and what did you get? That is, what was the either the revenues or the EBITDA? And what were the costs of your 2 small acquisitions?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we don't -- I mean, they're very small. And so we don't want to disclose all the details about them. But I can tell you the Ink Mill acquisition just has a few million dollars of revenue, so very small. It's a business that's really investing in o
componenttext: Yes. So we don't -- I mean, they're very small. And so we don't want to disclose all the details about them. But I can tell you the Ink Mill acquisition just has a few million dollars of revenue, so very small. It's a business that's really investing in our high-value reflectives business but it's also a capability we think we can leverage elsewhere within the portfolio as well. They make UV and UV LED curable inks. And as part of our traffic jet solution within that business. And then on PragmatIC, so that was an investment you haven't -- was earlier in October, so it's not in the results right now. That's a minority investment. There was an GBP 18 million funding round that PragmatIC went through. We were less than half of that, I will say.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Why is your PSM growing faster than the U.S? Or are there particular markets in Europe that are healthier or more robust? And are there particular PSM markets in the U.S. that are a little lackluster?
componenttext: Why is your PSM growing faster than the U.S? Or are there particular markets in Europe that are healthier or more robust? And are there particular PSM markets in the U.S. that are a little lackluster?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Europe, broadly speaking, gets the benefit of Eastern Europe emerging markets. And that's the Eastern Europe this quarter is what really was a key driver for them. But actually pretty consistently, for the past years, even Western Europe we've talked abou
componenttext: Europe, broadly speaking, gets the benefit of Eastern Europe emerging markets. And that's the Eastern Europe this quarter is what really was a key driver for them. But actually pretty consistently, for the past years, even Western Europe we've talked about growth being higher than the U.S. And there's a number of factors behind that. We can't point to anyone. One of them is regulatory requirements around larger label sizes and so forth. So there is not one thing I can point to that is 1 example. But to be honest, it's the differential between the U.S. and Western Europe has pretty much consistently been a little bit bigger than we would have been expected. And I'm talking about the market level not just our performance.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in the weakness in the U.S., was it confined to a particular market? Or it's too hard to tell?
componenttext: And then in the weakness in the U.S., was it confined to a particular market? Or it's too hard to tell?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not a particular market. No, it's relatively broad-based.
componenttext: Not a particular market. No, it's relatively broad-based.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to come back to RFID and RBIS a little bit. So recognizing you're not giving guidance here for 2017. Do you think, Mitch, over the next couple of years, let's frame it that way, that the outlook for adoption is as good as what we've seen, say, over
componenttext: I want to come back to RFID and RBIS a little bit. So recognizing you're not giving guidance here for 2017. Do you think, Mitch, over the next couple of years, let's frame it that way, that the outlook for adoption is as good as what we've seen, say, over the trailing 12 months? I recognize it's retailer by retailer, et cetera, and it can come in fairly large chunks. But if you had to frame it, is it as good, better, somewhat worse? How would you have us consider it over the next couple of years?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say, it's as good and getting better. So basically, a year or so ago, we were saying -- talking about getting to an infection point, starting to see some customers adopt. We've seen that. But it's really hard to call when that will happen to the point
componenttext: I'd say, it's as good and getting better. So basically, a year or so ago, we were saying -- talking about getting to an infection point, starting to see some customers adopt. We've seen that. But it's really hard to call when that will happen to the point you raise. I mean, next year, we expect this business to be double digit growth. It could be just over 10% or it could be 30%. So timing specifically is hard to tell, but over the long run, we definitely -- we've talked about this business being a 20% growth business and that's what we continue to expect.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, are the returns getting better to the retailer from adoption that's why the growth has been so strong? Are there other reasons why you'd see adoption? I would imagine have to be the former but again just want to get your thoughts on that.
componenttext: Mitch, are the returns getting better to the retailer from adoption that's why the growth has been so strong? Are there other reasons why you'd see adoption? I would imagine have to be the former but again just want to get your thoughts on that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's just more -- it's retailer by retailer and brand by brand, them going through the process. It's a pretty big shift in how they do things, of how thinking about running their supply chains, so the returns have been strong, very strong last few
componenttext: I think it's just more -- it's retailer by retailer and brand by brand, them going through the process. It's a pretty big shift in how they do things, of how thinking about running their supply chains, so the returns have been strong, very strong last few years for adoption. It just eats business, eats customer needs to go through that assessment and evaluation and the recent pilots can take so long and early adoption phase can take a while is just purely because of the changes in adjustments they need to make.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Back to the margin question from earlier and again, I -- we've talked about that before, and yes, I was aware that you have the drop off in D&A, the roll-off from PACs are there. so if I look at the low end of your range, I guess, I will drill down
componenttext: Okay. Back to the margin question from earlier and again, I -- we've talked about that before, and yes, I was aware that you have the drop off in D&A, the roll-off from PACs are there. so if I look at the low end of your range, I guess, I will drill down and say what makes you comfortable about getting that incremental 100 basis points or so? When I look at 2016, obviously, a lot of restructuring benefit to your credit, but yet the margins are, at least in this quarter, kind of flat versus the year ago. So is it just for the restructuring that drives the majority of that 100 basis points? Is it more in your view the RFID element, which you're quite obviously positive on? What gives you confidence in, at least, capturing that last 100 basis points above and beyond the D&A component?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really a balance between driving the growth strategy as well as driving further productivity. And if you look at the business, we've consistently delivered over 0.5 point a year of margin expansion regardless of what's going on at the top line. And i
componenttext: It's really a balance between driving the growth strategy as well as driving further productivity. And if you look at the business, we've consistently delivered over 0.5 point a year of margin expansion regardless of what's going on at the top line. And if you look over the last few years, we've grown this business 2.5%. So our objective here is ensure we can get those margin targets even in a lower growth scenario than the 4% to 5% we had targeted. And we will get there even in this lower growth environment and ensuring there's upside as we develop and push through our growth strategy so that when we start achieving that 4% to 5% growth, which is still our goal, you will then have further uplift from there.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
