componenttext: First off, did you see any measurable change in core sales growth for PSM in any particular month during 3Q? There have been some companies and different industries that have commented on the slowdown in Europe during the quarter, wondering if you saw any deviation in the quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, so we do normally see some variation month-to-month. We did see a little bit of a slide during Q3 over in Europe. Having said that, we're seeing a little bit of an uptick in early October as well within Europe as well as North America. So I don't re
componenttext: Well, so we do normally see some variation month-to-month. We did see a little bit of a slide during Q3 over in Europe. Having said that, we're seeing a little bit of an uptick in early October as well within Europe as well as North America. So I don't read too much into individual month trends too closely because it's not unusual for us to see 4 weeks of strong performance followed by a softening or vice versa.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then what exactly, Mitch, is do you think driving the weakness in North American PSM? Is that just sort of inventory reductions? What do you think is going on by channel there?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then what exactly, Mitch, is do you think driving the weakness in North American PSM? Is that just sort of inventory reductions? What do you think is going on by channel there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's hard to say. We think there's been a softening in the end consumption of the market in Q3, but we don't have that data right now. But we also did cede some share earlier in the year within that business as we're driving more discipline on the lower v
componenttext: It's hard to say. We think there's been a softening in the end consumption of the market in Q3, but we don't have that data right now. But we also did cede some share earlier in the year within that business as we're driving more discipline on the lower value, less differentiated segments. But in the quarter, we think this -- it basically softened a bit. We don't have clear reasons why. At Labelexpo, the sentiment from North American converters was overall I'd say, most of them were very confident in their individual businesses, cautious about the market overall. But also talked about how they themselves, have less visibility to their own order volumes than they traditionally have had as well. So it's hard to give you a read on exactly what's going on in the North American business. Clearly, some of the decline was from Graphics, if you will, within that region specifically. But it's hard to give you a clear read here. As I said, first few weeks of October, we're starting to see an uptick.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and just one final one for me. You also called out higher raw material costs for 3Q, can you first off expand on that? And then also, how were you kind of positioning the company for what could be an increase in inflation as we head into 2017 coming
componenttext: Okay, and just one final one for me. You also called out higher raw material costs for 3Q, can you first off expand on that? And then also, how were you kind of positioning the company for what could be an increase in inflation as we head into 2017 coming off a period of -- a few quarters anyway -- of deflation?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Ghansham, so we -- what we really said was that we saw the -- an impact to our margins of price net of raw material input costs. And so relatively speaking, we don't give specific color on pricing inflation, but as we've been pretty consistent in say
componenttext: Yes. Ghansham, so we -- what we really said was that we saw the -- an impact to our margins of price net of raw material input costs. And so relatively speaking, we don't give specific color on pricing inflation, but as we've been pretty consistent in saying that we broadly have given some price reductions in segments where we have relatively higher variable margins and where we may have seen some deflation. And we're basically then passing it along to customers in some targeted areas. And in our -- in my script, I specifically called out that we'd seen that, that impact in North America.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Louis Gaffner with Barclays Capital.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Scott Louis Gaffner with Barclays Capital.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, just wanted to go back to RBIS for a second. You mentioned the North American apparel retailers and some of the import data, are there any categories in particular within that channel that you're seeing any weakness in? And then what about European
componenttext: Mitch, just wanted to go back to RBIS for a second. You mentioned the North American apparel retailers and some of the import data, are there any categories in particular within that channel that you're seeing any weakness in? And then what about European retailers? If you could give some color there as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the categories within the U.S. department stores in particular, are seeing softness, and we're seeing that as well with our key customers in that space. But generally, I think it's relatively broad-based in the data that Anne shared is across the
componenttext: Yes, so the categories within the U.S. department stores in particular, are seeing softness, and we're seeing that as well with our key customers in that space. But generally, I think it's relatively broad-based in the data that Anne shared is across the entire retail apparel sector, if you will. So inventory levels returned to back this year to their prerecession high. If you recall for a few years after the recession, they were quite a bit lower. Those have bulked up. A good portion of that relates to the fact that it was a very warm winter last year and just there was not as much as sell-through as they've been holding onto the inventory. So I know the goal is for retailers to flush some of that inventory out of the system through this holiday season. And then for Europe, it depends. I'd say, overall, so softness in U.K. Clearly, the U.K. retailers with Brexit going on, I think, are struggling a bit. And so that's one place we see softness. But in Germany, pretty solid. Other markets, we're seeing relatively solid performance at the end retail level.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And any -- you said RFID up 30% in the quarter. With some of the weakness in apparel, are there any change in the conversation with your customers around adoption rates on RFID?
componenttext: Okay. And any -- you said RFID up 30% in the quarter. With some of the weakness in apparel, are there any change in the conversation with your customers around adoption rates on RFID?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it was up 35% in the quarter, and we expect to be 30% for the full year, expecting the growth to moderate a bit going into -- quite a bit going into Q4. The conversation is very similar. Working through in each retailer or brand -- need to go thro
componenttext: Yes, so it was up 35% in the quarter, and we expect to be 30% for the full year, expecting the growth to moderate a bit going into -- quite a bit going into Q4. The conversation is very similar. Working through in each retailer or brand -- need to go through an assessment of the business case and then piloting and then you get a partial adoption and full adoption. So no real change in the conversations. There's been in the last quarter since we talked about where the pipeline is, we've had one Tier 1 move from pilot into early adoption and then a couple of very small specialty retailers move either from business case to pilot or pilot to adoption. So conversation's pretty much the same, seeing a little bit of a migration through the pipeline as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Last one for me, just around the share repurchases. I mean, obviously you don't make a decision based on 1 day's move, but the stock is down fairly dramatically today, and I would think your internal model would be screening well for share buyback h
componenttext: Okay. Last one for me, just around the share repurchases. I mean, obviously you don't make a decision based on 1 day's move, but the stock is down fairly dramatically today, and I would think your internal model would be screening well for share buyback here. How do you think about share buyback into the end of the year?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as you talk about, we don't really comment on timing and pace of share buyback, but -- and we've been really consistent in how we look at this. But we look -- we do have an intrinsic value model. And as we see the gap -- if we see a gap widening, we wi
componenttext: So as you talk about, we don't really comment on timing and pace of share buyback, but -- and we've been really consistent in how we look at this. But we look -- we do have an intrinsic value model. And as we see the gap -- if we see a gap widening, we will be much more aggressive in buying back stock. And again as we see the gap -- less of a gap, then we don't buy back as much stock at that point. So we are a bit opportunistic in how we look at our share buyback programs as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Scott, we don't comment, but you can probably infer from our past behavior how we would behave in such an environment.
componenttext: Yes. So Scott, we don't comment, but you can probably infer from our past behavior how we would behave in such an environment.

componenttextpreview: I guess the first question I had, recognizing the answer is probably both, when we look at the slight reduction in the core growth rate you're expecting, Mitch, is it more centered in RBIS, given the weakness in retail? Or is it in the somewhat difficult
componenttext: I guess the first question I had, recognizing the answer is probably both, when we look at the slight reduction in the core growth rate you're expecting, Mitch, is it more centered in RBIS, given the weakness in retail? Or is it in the somewhat difficult to pin down but nonetheless apparent reduction in consumption in Pressure-sensitive Materials in, I think, the U.S. is what you said? Which one of those is a bigger driver of this modest trend there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So George, are you asking about Q3 or Q4 because you can kind of triangulate what that actually takes...
componenttext: So George, are you asking about Q3 or Q4 because you can kind of triangulate what that actually takes...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was meaning it really more for the full year outlook, but answer it however you feel is most illustrative.
componenttext: I was meaning it really more for the full year outlook, but answer it however you feel is most illustrative.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So overall, I mean, RBIS you can see where the growth rate is, a little over 2%. And so we expect roughly a continuation of that. Obviously, it can be a little lower, a little higher, depending on how things pan out and a couple of key contributing f
componenttext: Yes. So overall, I mean, RBIS you can see where the growth rate is, a little over 2%. And so we expect roughly a continuation of that. Obviously, it can be a little lower, a little higher, depending on how things pan out and a couple of key contributing factors. We have harder RFID comps, if you will. We have a couple of things that ease up on the comps front in that business. So that's what we're thinking within RBIS as a continuation. And within pressure sensitive, the Q3, the revenue was lower than we're thinking that business would come in at, and it was specifically around North America. And so it's really a question about is it early trends we see in October continue a positive trend that we're seeing? Or does it revert back to a lower level?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Is October more or less in line with what you would have expected otherwise? And obviously, it's up -- but is it up where you would have liked it to have been?
componenttext: Okay. Is October more or less in line with what you would have expected otherwise? And obviously, it's up -- but is it up where you would have liked it to have been?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's consistent with our guidance range that we've provided. One thing, it's very hard to read Asia, North Asia in particular because of the calendar shift of the Golden Week, so basically their harvest festival, if you will. So that distorted things. So
componenttext: It's consistent with our guidance range that we've provided. One thing, it's very hard to read Asia, North Asia in particular because of the calendar shift of the Golden Week, so basically their harvest festival, if you will. So that distorted things. So anything for RBIS because so much is sourced out of North Asia as well as North Asia for materials group, is not a good read. North America rebounded like we said, and Europe has rebounded a little bit from the softening late Q3 as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Now one other question I had, if I look at the guidance increase, and it was roughly $0.10. The tax effect in the third quarter is probably a couple of pennies. The FX negative is about a couple of pennies more favorable. Is there a way to split the
componenttext: Okay. Now one other question I had, if I look at the guidance increase, and it was roughly $0.10. The tax effect in the third quarter is probably a couple of pennies. The FX negative is about a couple of pennies more favorable. Is there a way to split the remaining difference between restructuring what you said is in excess of $75 million, but you didn't necessarily say how much, and any other factors that are benefiting you?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really the biggest piece of the gap that you are talking about, it's from the beat that we had with PSM this quarter. So even though the restructuring -- we gave guidance, it's a slightly -- it's just slightly more than $75 million. We -- it could be
componenttext: It's really the biggest piece of the gap that you are talking about, it's from the beat that we had with PSM this quarter. So even though the restructuring -- we gave guidance, it's a slightly -- it's just slightly more than $75 million. We -- it could be a couple million or we just want to give a bit of flavor on that, but it's really the operational beat we had this quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. My last one and then I'll turn it over and try to come back. Back to RBIS, and we've asked similar questions, I guess, in the past around the business and your need to restructure. Recognizing it's a challenging business and it's competitive, at the
componenttext: Okay. My last one and then I'll turn it over and try to come back. Back to RBIS, and we've asked similar questions, I guess, in the past around the business and your need to restructure. Recognizing it's a challenging business and it's competitive, at the same time, you're continuing to restructure and you're trying to stay ahead of kind of the pace of competition and the other challenges in that market. At this juncture, given what you know, what 2 or 3 things make you confident that you can continue to retool that business, stay ahead of competition and ultimately hit your margin targets for RBIS by 2018?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think, overall, what makes us confident around that is the adjustments that we made -- started making last year, that we talked through and it was the beginning of what we said would be a multiyear transformation. We made quite a few adjustments
componenttext: Yes. So I think, overall, what makes us confident around that is the adjustments that we made -- started making last year, that we talked through and it was the beginning of what we said would be a multiyear transformation. We made quite a few adjustments, and a lot of that was around moving more decision-making into the regions and closer to the customer, having a more segmented approach depending -- different customers if it's a performance athletic, high-end performance athletic brand relative to a discounted retailer, they have different needs so we've adopted a more segmented approach. And as part of that, in some of the -- in some segments, that meant adjusting our cost structure to: one, expand margin; but two, also to get more price competitive. Remember that the variable margins in this business, even in what we call the less differentiated, are relatively high. And so being able to drive consistent growth is a key requirement within this business as well. So -- what's -- what are the signs of success? It's basically we're getting volume gains. We've stopped the share slide that we had for a couple of years going into mid last year. And we're seeing volume gains even though the market is down. And we've basically proven the model ourselves internally so now it's a matter of pushing forward to accelerate. And as far as just to get to the margin target that we've laid out for 2018, if you recall, when we laid those out, we identified, there's a lot amortization expense going away late in the cycle. So we got to have basically the full point of expansion just from that. That's not new. We talked about it when we first laid out the targets. So that gives you a full point. And then from there, from where we expect to be this year, you need less than a point of margin expansion over 2 years to get to the low end and less than 2 points to get to the high end.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson with KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Adam Josephson with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Forgive me, I joined in a bit late so forgive me if I'm repeating anything, but it sounds like you reduced -- you slightly reduced your organic sales growth guidance on account of some weakness in North America and PSM. Am I on the mark so far?
componenttext: Forgive me, I joined in a bit late so forgive me if I'm repeating anything, but it sounds like you reduced -- you slightly reduced your organic sales growth guidance on account of some weakness in North America and PSM. Am I on the mark so far?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we -- when we looked at our guidance, yes, we came in a little bit softer on the -- on North America for PSM. But I think if you look at the full year guidance, the reality is we're going to be around the midpoint. If you look at the 2 ranges, you
componenttext: Yes. So we -- when we looked at our guidance, yes, we came in a little bit softer on the -- on North America for PSM. But I think if you look at the full year guidance, the reality is we're going to be around the midpoint. If you look at the 2 ranges, you'd have to assume a pretty significant change in the run rate in Q4 for the businesses. And on the downside piece to it, you'd have to assume a reversal in trend for all the businesses as well. So the likelihood is we're going to be around the midpoint.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: But -- and you raised your guidance partly on tax, and I think you said partly on better PSM? Is that right?
componenttext: But -- and you raised your guidance partly on tax, and I think you said partly on better PSM? Is that right?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Correct. And I will quote, clarify on the tax, that's really a contributor from PSM as well. We saw very favorable geo mix of where the income was coming from, from the lower tax jurisdictions. So I really consider that kind of operational beat as well.
componenttext: Correct. And I will quote, clarify on the tax, that's really a contributor from PSM as well. We saw very favorable geo mix of where the income was coming from, from the lower tax jurisdictions. So I really consider that kind of operational beat as well.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you have -- so just -- so you have lower sales expectations for PSM broadly, but you have higher profit expectations for PSM for the year presumably on margins, right?
componenttext: So you have -- so just -- so you have lower sales expectations for PSM broadly, but you have higher profit expectations for PSM for the year presumably on margins, right?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016

componenttext: Correct.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And that's -- and why the margin upside, given the sales -- given that sales are a bit light?
componenttext: And that's -- and why the margin upside, given the sales -- given that sales are a bit light?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So again, a similar story than what we've had in the last couple of quarters is productivity continues to be a very strong performer for this division. And in this quarter, we continued to deliver on the productivity front. So really the beat we had
componenttext: Yes. So again, a similar story than what we've had in the last couple of quarters is productivity continues to be a very strong performer for this division. And in this quarter, we continued to deliver on the productivity front. So really the beat we had that we're showing for the full year guidance came from this quarter.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just in terms of your implied 4Q guidance, it's the midpoint around $0.95 compared to last year's $0.85. Last year, you had a pretty low tax rate. So can you just help us understand what the primary drivers of that year-over-year growth are?
componenttext: Okay. And just in terms of your implied 4Q guidance, it's the midpoint around $0.95 compared to last year's $0.85. Last year, you had a pretty low tax rate. So can you just help us understand what the primary drivers of that year-over-year growth are?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So for our guidance, for the margin, we would assume the normal seasonal margin, sequential margin pieces from Q3 to Q4 for PSM. And we are -- and traditionally the RBIS business does have a higher margin sequentially from Q3 to Q4 that we also have baked
componenttext: So for our guidance, for the margin, we would assume the normal seasonal margin, sequential margin pieces from Q3 to Q4 for PSM. And we are -- and traditionally the RBIS business does have a higher margin sequentially from Q3 to Q4 that we also have baked in. So you look at our guidance range really the biggest component of it is where will the margins deliver for RBIS.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari with Citigroup Global Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Anthony Pettinari with Citigroup Global Markets.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the investment in Luxembourg, is it possible to say when the capacity becomes available or when it ramps? And then how much of that $65 million investment shows up in 2016 CapEx versus 2017? And kind of any early view on 2017 CapEx?
componenttext: With the investment in Luxembourg, is it possible to say when the capacity becomes available or when it ramps? And then how much of that $65 million investment shows up in 2016 CapEx versus 2017? And kind of any early view on 2017 CapEx?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So just specifically with that investment, it's coming online essentially for the year '18. 2018 is when it will be up and running, so that's our expectation. And if you look at the investment that we're making, we've consistently talked about pretty
componenttext: Yes. So just specifically with that investment, it's coming online essentially for the year '18. 2018 is when it will be up and running, so that's our expectation. And if you look at the investment that we're making, we've consistently talked about pretty robust growth within Europe, both Western Europe, but also the combination of Western Europe and Eastern Europe. So this is a business that actually we haven't added a new coder in for labels for quite a number of years. And so this is to fund the growth that we're seeing within that business right now, and we expect we'll continue to be investing in that region because we see quite a bit of opportunity for continued growth there. As far as the CapEx timing, Anne, you want to comment?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So generally, the bulk of the CapEx timing will take place in 2017. And the spending that we have this year is within the guidance that we gave at the beginning of the year of roughly $200 million for CapEx. And again, when we laid out our 2018 targe
componenttext: Yes. So generally, the bulk of the CapEx timing will take place in 2017. And the spending that we have this year is within the guidance that we gave at the beginning of the year of roughly $200 million for CapEx. And again, when we laid out our 2018 targets, we said that on average, we would spend about $200 million in CapEx over the years. We were a little behind in the first couple of years of that guidance range, so I would expect to see it still average around the $200 million. It's just going to be a little more back weighted overall for the company.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Okay, that's very helpful. And then in RBIS, I think last quarter, you indicated you were impacted by store closures in athletic goods. And I'm wondering given what we've been reading in a very challenging retail environment, are store closures -- a
componenttext: Okay. Okay, that's very helpful. And then in RBIS, I think last quarter, you indicated you were impacted by store closures in athletic goods. And I'm wondering given what we've been reading in a very challenging retail environment, are store closures -- are they still a headwind in 3Q? And does that maybe a drag through the end of the year? Or any kind of color you can give there?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's always some consolidation of store closures. And what you see is what we see. Specifically, what we commented on before was the fact that there was some bankruptcies of some athletic store -- athletic chains. So -- and that affected performance at
componenttext: There's always some consolidation of store closures. And what you see is what we see. Specifically, what we commented on before was the fact that there was some bankruptcies of some athletic store -- athletic chains. So -- and that affected performance athletics. If you recall it had declined last quarter, which was exceptional because usually we see very consistent growth. So that category for us returned to growth in this past -- in Q3.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And maybe just one last one, and it's kind of a follow-up to George's question on RBIS. In your remarks, you referenced accelerating the RBIS margin improvement program. And I was wondering if you'd give a little color on the leverag
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And maybe just one last one, and it's kind of a follow-up to George's question on RBIS. In your remarks, you referenced accelerating the RBIS margin improvement program. And I was wondering if you'd give a little color on the leverage you can pull there from here on out. Do you need to get more aggressive on the price adjustments? Or are there additional cost that you can take out? Or would you get more aggressive on M&A? Or just how should we think about the levers you can pull to accelerate the RBIS margin improvement?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's just basically continued execution of what we've been doing but really taking the next step and accelerating what we have been doing. This is about winning in the marketplace. And I'll tell you from what we're seeing and what we're heari
componenttext: Yes, I think it's just basically continued execution of what we've been doing but really taking the next step and accelerating what we have been doing. This is about winning in the marketplace. And I'll tell you from what we're seeing and what we're hearing from customers, the change that we made are resonating. That gives us confidence. We're seeing the numbers behind that, of volume gains in a period of declining market conditions. So that gives us confidence. And we just see opportunity to run this business more efficiently as well. So there's quite a few levers within a business of that size and don't want to go through each of the individual details. But we feel not pleased with where the performance is, but confident with the prospects of this business and what we're going to deliver.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Rosemarie Morbelli with Gabelli & Company.

componenttext: So this can have a little bit of volatility to it, but it's consistently grown above the average for the overall segment and pretty relatively consistently mid-single digits to higher. So -- and that's where it was within Q3.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And could you give us some detail as to the inventory increase? I mean, versus last year, inventory is up 10% versus revenues, up 2.7%. Is this Mactac? Or is something else going on?
componenttext: Okay. And could you give us some detail as to the inventory increase? I mean, versus last year, inventory is up 10% versus revenues, up 2.7%. Is this Mactac? Or is something else going on?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Rosemarie, there's a couple of components to it. Yes, this is the first quarter that we got Mactac in our balance sheet so that will distort some of your ratios a little bit. But in general, a couple of quarters ago we talked about the fact that we wer
componenttext: So Rosemarie, there's a couple of components to it. Yes, this is the first quarter that we got Mactac in our balance sheet so that will distort some of your ratios a little bit. But in general, a couple of quarters ago we talked about the fact that we were making some investments in certain select areas in inventory primarily in RFID with RBIS. And so while we have continued to make progress and we have seen that inventory reductions come down as we've played out the year, we still have an investment in that in order to carry us through the end of this year and to next year.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So this is making sure you have the proper inventory in anticipation of the changes you are making?
componenttext: So this is making sure you have the proper inventory in anticipation of the changes you are making?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's the pipeline of RFID customers that we've got to make sure that we're meeting their demands.
componenttext: It's the pipeline of RFID customers that we've got to make sure that we're meeting their demands.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I may ask one last one. Your ratio price -- selling price versus cost was negative as raw material costs seem to be rising. Are you expecting that ratio to worsen in the few quarters until you manage to get price up in line with raw material cost
componenttext: Okay. If I may ask one last one. Your ratio price -- selling price versus cost was negative as raw material costs seem to be rising. Are you expecting that ratio to worsen in the few quarters until you manage to get price up in line with raw material cost?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So raw material cost, the environment we're seeing is relatively stable. You see some commodities like oil have been on an upswing. But as far as what we're experiencing, they've been relatively stable. And as far as the net impact of price and raw materi
componenttext: So raw material cost, the environment we're seeing is relatively stable. You see some commodities like oil have been on an upswing. But as far as what we're experiencing, they've been relatively stable. And as far as the net impact of price and raw material cost, we -- Anne talked about what the headwind was in the quarter. And over the long run, we've been pretty consistent in saying that some of the modest gains we've had in each quarter over the past couple of years basically over the long run, those eventually adjust for themselves, if you will, or correct. So we -- what we're seeing on the pricing -- net pricing front is what we expected. The outperformance in PSM was largely around continued productivity. And our objective here is to consistently grow this business leveraging our innovation capabilities, which includes finding ways to reduce the material content of our products so that we can be competitive in the marketplace and grow the market while driving returns and margins in this business.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And one very quick one, if I may. When are you -- when are we anniversary-ing the program loss in Performance Tapes?
componenttext: And one very quick one, if I may. When are you -- when are we anniversary-ing the program loss in Performance Tapes?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we had a small piece of that in the first half of the year, but I would expect to see headwinds in the second half as the program loss we really start feeling that in Q3.
componenttext: So we had a small piece of that in the first half of the year, but I would expect to see headwinds in the second half as the program loss we really start feeling that in Q3.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's basically mid-next year is the rough rule of thumb you should use, Rosemarie.
componenttext: It's basically mid-next year is the rough rule of thumb you should use, Rosemarie.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next quarter comes from the line of Jeffrey John Zekauskas with JPMorgan Securities.
componenttext: Our next quarter comes from the line of Jeffrey John Zekauskas with JPMorgan Securities.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I guess I'd like to go back to raw materials. I understand that your raw material costs were pretty benign, but propylene costs are up $0.10 a pound since April. And so that's going to move up acrylic prices in the fourth and in the first quarter. So i
componenttext: So I guess I'd like to go back to raw materials. I understand that your raw material costs were pretty benign, but propylene costs are up $0.10 a pound since April. And so that's going to move up acrylic prices in the fourth and in the first quarter. So is your attitude that you're going to wait and see as the raw material costs move up, if they do move up, before you take pricing action? Or are you going to try to be more aggressive? What's your stance as some of the petrochemical values move up?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we saw a little bit of modest inflation that we talked about last quarter, but we've seen relative stability. And individual components, Jeff, move in different directions, but on balance is where we're seeing things fairly muted, if you will. So
componenttext: Yes. So we saw a little bit of modest inflation that we talked about last quarter, but we've seen relative stability. And individual components, Jeff, move in different directions, but on balance is where we're seeing things fairly muted, if you will. So that's what we were referring to, not any individual components. You're absolutely right. What you're seeing is what we're seeing for that component. But what we do is when there is inflation -- if so, if we were to start seeing inflation, we go through and we will announce price increases on which products or which regions it's affecting. And a good example of that is last year, we were still in a relatively deflationary environment. We raised prices within filament categories within Europe. So we went out and announced it and pushed it through. So you've really got to think through about -- with the commodities we're seeing is different in U.S. dollars or if you are in euros, and so we basically make adjustments and we'll put price increases through where we see inflation.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. You made a couple of small acquisitions. What did you pay for them and what did you get? That is, what was the either the revenues or the EBITDA? And what were the costs of your 2 small acquisitions?
componenttext: Okay. You made a couple of small acquisitions. What did you pay for them and what did you get? That is, what was the either the revenues or the EBITDA? And what were the costs of your 2 small acquisitions?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we don't -- I mean, they're very small. And so we don't want to disclose all the details about them. But I can tell you the Ink Mill acquisition just has a few million dollars of revenue, so very small. It's a business that's really investing in o
componenttext: Yes. So we don't -- I mean, they're very small. And so we don't want to disclose all the details about them. But I can tell you the Ink Mill acquisition just has a few million dollars of revenue, so very small. It's a business that's really investing in our high-value reflectives business, but it's also a capability we think we can leverage elsewhere within the portfolio as well. They make UV and UV LED curable inks. And it's part of our traffic jet solution within that business. And then on PragmatIC, so that was an investment you haven't -- was earlier in October, so it's not in the results right now. That's a minority investment. There was an GBP 18 million funding round that PragmatIC went through. We were less than half of that, I will say.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Why is Europe PSM growing faster than the U.S? Or are there particular markets in Europe that are healthier or more robust? And are there particular PSM markets in the U.S. that are a little lackluster?
componenttext: Why is Europe PSM growing faster than the U.S? Or are there particular markets in Europe that are healthier or more robust? And are there particular PSM markets in the U.S. that are a little lackluster?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Europe, broadly speaking, gets the benefit of Eastern Europe emerging markets. And that's the Eastern Europe this quarter is what really was a key driver for them. But actually pretty consistently, for the past years, even Western Europe we've talked abou
componenttext: Europe, broadly speaking, gets the benefit of Eastern Europe emerging markets. And that's the Eastern Europe this quarter is what really was a key driver for them. But actually pretty consistently, for the past years, even Western Europe we've talked about growth being higher than the U.S. And there's a number of factors behind that. We can't point to any one. One of them is regulatory requirements around larger label sizes and so forth. So there is not one thing I can point to that's one example. But to be honest, it's the differential between the U.S. and Western Europe has pretty much consistently been a little bit bigger than we would have been expected. And I'm talking about the market level not just our performance.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in the weakness in the U.S., was it confined to a particular market? Or it's too hard to tell?
componenttext: And then in the weakness in the U.S., was it confined to a particular market? Or it's too hard to tell?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not a particular market. No, it's relatively broad-based.
componenttext: Not a particular market. No, it's relatively broad-based.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We have a follow-up question from the line of George Leon Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We have a follow-up question from the line of George Leon Staphos with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to come back to RFID and RBIS a little bit. So recognizing you're not giving guidance here for 2017. Do you think, Mitch, over the next couple of years, let's frame it that way, that the outlook for adoption is as good as what we've seen, say, over
componenttext: I want to come back to RFID and RBIS a little bit. So recognizing you're not giving guidance here for 2017. Do you think, Mitch, over the next couple of years, let's frame it that way, that the outlook for adoption is as good as what we've seen, say, over the trailing 12 months? I recognize it's retailer by retailer, et cetera, and it can come in fairly large chunks. But if you had to frame it, is it as good, better, somewhat worse? How would you have us consider it over the next couple of years?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd say, it's as good and getting better. So basically, a year or so ago, we were saying -- talking about getting into an inflection point, starting to see some customers adopt. We've seen that. But it's really hard to call when that will happen to the po
componenttext: I'd say, it's as good and getting better. So basically, a year or so ago, we were saying -- talking about getting into an inflection point, starting to see some customers adopt. We've seen that. But it's really hard to call when that will happen to the point you raised. I mean, next year, we expect this business to be double digit growth. It could be just over 10% or it could be 30%. So timing it specifically is hard to tell, but over the long run, we definitely -- we've talked about this business being a 20% growth business and that's what we continue to expect.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mitch, are the returns getting better to the retailer from adoption that's why the growth has been so strong? Are there other reasons why you'd see adoption? I would imagine have to be the former but again just want to get your thoughts on that.
componenttext: Mitch, are the returns getting better to the retailer from adoption that's why the growth has been so strong? Are there other reasons why you'd see adoption? I would imagine have to be the former but again just want to get your thoughts on that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's just more -- it's retailer by retailer and brand by brand, them going through the process. It's a pretty big shift in how they do things, of how they think about running their supply chains, so the returns have been strong, very strong, last
componenttext: I think it's just more -- it's retailer by retailer and brand by brand, them going through the process. It's a pretty big shift in how they do things, of how they think about running their supply chains, so the returns have been strong, very strong, last few years for adoption. It's just each business, each customer needs to go through that assessment and evaluation and the reason pilots can take so long and the early adoption phase can take a while, is just purely because of the changes in adjustments they need to make.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Back to the margin question from earlier and again, I -- we've talked about this before, and yes, I was aware that you have the drop off in D&A, the roll-off from PACs [ph] are there. So if I look at the low end of your range, I guess, I would drill
componenttext: Okay. Back to the margin question from earlier and again, I -- we've talked about this before, and yes, I was aware that you have the drop off in D&A, the roll-off from PACs [ph] are there. So if I look at the low end of your range, I guess, I would drill down and say what makes you comfortable about getting that incremental 100 basis points or so? When I look at 2016, obviously, a lot of restructuring benefit to your credit, but yet the margins are, at least in this quarter, kind of flat versus the year ago. So is it just further restructuring that drives the majority of that 100 basis points? Is it more in your view the RFID element, which you're quite obviously positive on? What gives you confidence in, at least, capturing that last 100 basis points above and beyond the D&A component?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really a balance between driving the growth strategy as well as driving further productivity. And if you look at the business, we've consistently delivered over 0.5 point a year of margin expansion regardless of what's going on at the top line. And i
componenttext: It's really a balance between driving the growth strategy as well as driving further productivity. And if you look at the business, we've consistently delivered over 0.5 point a year of margin expansion regardless of what's going on at the top line. And if you looked over the last few years, we've grown this business 2.5%. So our objective here is ensure we can get those margin targets even in a lower growth scenario than the 4% to 5% we had targeted. And we will get there even in this lower growth environment and ensuring there's upside as we develop and push through our growth strategy so that when we start achieving that 4% to 5% growth, which is still our goal, you will then have further uplift from there.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I guess my last question and I'll turn it over, actually 2-part -- 2 questions, I apologize. The Pressure-sensitive mix, what was negative in the quarter? I remember reading in the release but I don't remember what your comments were here o
componenttext: Okay. And then I guess my last question and I'll turn it over, actually 2-part -- 2 questions, I apologize. The Pressure-sensitive mix, what was negative in the quarter? I remember reading in the release but I don't remember what your comments were here on the call. And then the extra sales week in the fourth quarter from last year, I don't -- I seem to remember that not really having much of an effect on earnings but I just wanted to verify that.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks. So the mix was primarily in 2 different areas. First was the customer application that we had discussed in the personal care space for tapes. And then the second piece was North America, primarily in the high-value segments, but we've been talking
componenttext: Thanks. So the mix was primarily in 2 different areas. First was the customer application that we had discussed in the personal care space for tapes. And then the second piece was North America, primarily in the high-value segments, but we've been talking about the North America volumes as well. So those were the 2 pieces of the mix. It was geo mix as well as the customer tapes. As far as the 53rd week, that was really...

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Anne, just on that, I thought emerging markets tended to be higher margin for you? So why would North America being a little bit weak, be negative for mix?
componenttext: Anne, just on that, I thought emerging markets tended to be higher margin for you? So why would North America being a little bit weak, be negative for mix?

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as far as on the geo mix comment, George, our margins we've said are higher where we have higher relative market share. And North America, we have relatively high relative market share.
componenttext: Yes. So as far as on the geo mix comment, George, our margins we've said are higher where we have higher relative market share. And North America, we have relatively high relative market share.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry about that. Anne, go ahead.
componenttext: Sorry about that. Anne, go ahead.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the 53rd week, that was really a 2014, 2015 impact so you really wouldn't see anything for 2016.
componenttext: Okay. On the 53rd week, that was really a 2014, 2015 impact so you really wouldn't see anything for 2016.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mr. Butier, I will now turn the call back to you. Please continue with your presentation or closing remarks.
componenttext: Mr. Butier, I will now turn the call back to you. Please continue with your presentation or closing remarks.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you. Well, thanks, everybody, for joining the call. Again, I'm pleased with the progress we're making against both our strategic and financial objectives, and we remain committed to achieving our long-term targets for value creation. I want to
componenttext: Okay. Thank you. Well, thanks, everybody, for joining the call. Again, I'm pleased with the progress we're making against both our strategic and financial objectives, and we remain committed to achieving our long-term targets for value creation. I want to thank the entire team within Avery Dennison for their hard work and commitment to our success. So thank you.

headline: Avery Dennison Corporation, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 26, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude the conference call for today. We thank you for your participation and ask that you please disconnect your lines.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, that does conclude the conference call for today. We thank you for your participation and ask that you please disconnect your lines.
